input_doc: I got the red version of this cover and I love it!! It works in every program I use.  I love the 360 turn radius.  It is a great quality and very sturdy.  All those that said it broke must have abused it because I am not really super careful with turning it and mine is great!!!

I was going on a trip to Japan, and so was anxious to get the 2 lb. Eee-pc rather than lugging around my 7 lb Lenovo.  For the most part the eee-pc worked fine.  It boots quickly, has a good user interface (except the file manager takes some getting used to), connects to the Internet (wire or wireless like a charm). However, I don't like Mozilla as a browser because it doesn't provide some of the services when used with Microsoft exchange server mail I tried and failed to find and install an alternative browser like Netscape.  Also, I needed a SFTP program, and failed to find one I could install. I guess I just don't get along well with Linux when it goes beyond pre-installed software.

The software included with the Eee-PC is worth the price of the machine itself -- The word processor opens and writes almost every format, the Presenter Program is compatible with PowerPoint, although has a limited number of designs (2).  However, when I hooked the machine to an LCD projector we could get the screen to switch resolutions to give a full projection (may have been my lack of understanding, but we had to switch the presentation to a full-size laptop).  I wanted to install the Open Office Database, but could figure out how to do that.

All the USB peripherals I used with the Eee-PC worked fine, including an HP all-in-one printer, external USB hard disk, and USB mouse.  The weakest part of the machine and the reason I returned it, was the keyboard and the mouse buttons on the touch pad.  The USB mouse solved the mouse button problem, but the keyboard was annoying, often missing letters or adding in double letters (bounce).  I could have used a USB keyboard but that defeats the purpose of buying a 2 lb machine. So, I understand there is a slightly larger format machine coming out in the summer -- maybe that will do the trick if they can keep the weight down and install a Windows XP operating system, I'd buy it.

input_doc: B L A Z I N G FAST!!!  I got 6 external vm's running on my Win10 laptop and the disk util was 5%.  I could have run more but my laptop was running out of available ram.
GREAT quality!! Need a cord to replace the one that came with your device, look no further!!! The short ones are great for purse-charging from a spare battery!

I wish I could rate it zero stars!! It NEVER worked!!! From the moment I turned it on it was frozen. I couldn't access the apps, I couldn't scroll, I couldn't adjust the time. All I could do was turn it on/off. This is the worst purchase I've ever made. I guess I couldn't have expected more based on the price.

input_doc:
We ordered this machine for it's awesome specs and the fantastic reviews. Buuuuuut when we received the package, the Dell box was opened (for some reason) and the machine didn't power on at all. After a few hours of troubleshooting, we determined that the computer arrived with a faulty power supply.

If your XPS Arrives, and it starts blinking amber as soon as you plug it in? It's your power supply, my friend. Return that sucker ASAP and get a replacement. If you don't trust Dell after that (we certainly didn't) then get that glorious, glorious refund you deserve!

UPDATE: After having this for just a few months we've had serious issues with quality. My daughter's broke within a month, but it was the dongle piece that fits in the computer that broke and she does carry it to classes, so it might have been knocked around. Then after only a few months (and too late for return), mine has stopped scrolling properly. I love the comfort and fit, and the price was very good, but not if you need to buy 2x/yr. I'm up in the air about what to replace it with - should I give it one more try?
----
I don't normally fall in love with new tech gadgets instantly, and I thought it might take a couple weeks to get used to a completely different mouse design. It felt comfortable and natural straight away. The pointer accuracy is there, the ergonomic design fits my medium sized hand comfortably, and the surface texture of the mouse just feels nice. Most importantly, it definitely relieves my discomfort. I'm left wondering why all mouses aren't made with the vertical design? Terrific value. I got one for my college kiddo and she loves it, too. I should have gotten this sooner.

input_doc:
Okay, so when I bought these, I didn't have high expectations.  I am rating three star mostly because the top speed I can get out of these is 200Mbps.  That is about 24MBps.

First of all, they claim to have 1000Mbps up and 1000Mbps down.  I tried various configurations and couldn't get them to get that speed.  Going through two breaks made the performance degrade down to 100Mbps.  Going through only one breaker gave me 200Mbps.  The only thing that I could think of on how someone could get 1000Mbps is if they were on the same breaker but this is unrealistic in most home solutions.

I did noticed after i plugged it into a switch and tried two different computers transferring a large file, the performance on one of them degraded in speed to almost 1MB/s which wasn't thrilling.  Still testing all of the capabilities.

If you purchase this, just don't have high expectations unless you will be on the same breaker.

input_doc:
Upgrading/downgrading (depends how you look at it) from Sony NEX 5N due to the lack of good/reasonably priced lens is getting frustrating. I want a camera that is smaller than DSLR, takes excellent photos, good prime lens selection and can take good video (i'm fine with 720 30p). The E-M5 seemed to fit the bill.

Overall, it takes the best m4/3 photos in low light that I've seen (I've used GF1, GX1, E-P3). But comparing kit lens to kit lens i like the jpeg output from the Sony better.

So why 3 Stars?
- Camera is really small but hefty. Both of these characteristics are good, but it makes it really hard to hold since there is barely any grip.
- On/off switch placement is awkward
- On/Off switch feel extremely flimsy like a piece of plastic that will eventually break off after extensive use.
- Humming sound upon power up. Sounds like my laptop when the fan is running.
- Video has strobe effect (background appears to be flashing) when zooming in or out.
- A lot of focus hunting when taking video using kit lens.
- Long and complex menu...I thought the Sony menu was bad, this is even more complex.
- Mushy and small buttons. Prefer hard plastic buttons instead.
- Flip screen, to get it 90 degrees facing up is a 2 step process. Sony is one.
- OLED has greenish/blue tint when viewed at a slight angle.
- Price....for $1.3K I can not overlook the issues mentioned above, maybe I'm expecting too much. If it was $400 cheaper then this is a 5 star camera and I can overlook those UX issues.
- planning to wait for the G5 or GH3 instead.

input_doc: ... I read the reviews submitted before my own, I thought that I'd be makin a good decision to purchase these headphones over the scores of others I considered. First thing I noticed when I got these headphones was; THEY ARE HUGE!!! I have big ears and my entire ear ended up sitting INSIDE the headphones  ear-cup, as opposed to having the outer rim press against my ears, having the inner ear cup aligned with my inner ear. Next thing I realized was, the headphones felt flimsy, and weak, and had exposed screws above the ear-cup, I thought I could overlook these factors if they actually SOUNDED GOOD, so I hooked them up to my computer. The sound was low and distant - the bass was virtually non-existent, the treble was thin, and I swear those volume controls on each side did nothing less than annoyed me. I thought it may have been my computer, so I tried it with a couple other portable devices, it sounded the same. I tried my $13 computer headphone/microphone set with my devices, and they sounded ALOT better! input_doc:
What is has:

7.0" 16M-color LCD capacitive touchscreen of 1024x600 pixel resolution; 170 ppi
Android OS v4.2.2 with TouchWiz
1.2 GHz dual-core Cortex-A9 CPU, GC1000 GPU, 1GB of RAM, Marvell PXA986 chipset
2 MP autofocus rear facing camera with face detection
VGA video recording at 24fps
8 GB internal storage, microSD slot max. 32GB
3G version with voice communication and SMS available - NOT included in this model
Wi-Fi 802.11 b/g/n support
GPS with A-GPS connectivity; GLONASS support
Stereo Bluetooth v4.0
microUSB port for charging, USB charging cable, wall adapter
Accelerometer sensor
Standard 3.5 mm audio jack
Document editor and file manager comes preinstalled
3600 mAh battery

Main disadvantages:

No USB OTG support - No HDMI port
Low screen resolution-1024x600
Feeble chipset-only 1GB RAM
Only one speaker and placed at the back
No front-facing camera

If you're looking for a compact and inexpensive tablet - one you wouldn't worry about getting lost or damaged - this is as good a choice as any. This tablet is a stripped down version of the Galaxy Tab 3.  Want to use SKYPE?  Sorry, no front facing camera.  Want to attach a USB stick, mouse or keyboard?  Sorry, no USB OTG support.  The tablet is extremely basic, primarily for tasks like reading and sending email, reading a book or magazine, watching Netflix or streaming music. The tablet works ok for what it is and I get about 6-9 hours out of the battery before recharge depending upon how I am using it.
The tablet will work well as a travel tablet, or one for the kids to use.  Just don't expect too much of it.

Competition:

The ASUS MeMo Pad HD7 costs the same as the Samsung tablet but has better screen resolution, faster quad-core processor, front camera, higher-res rear camera and is lighter.
The Lenovo IdeaTab A3000 matches the Lite in all aspects: display size and resolution, Android version, battery but adds a front camera, better rear camera, USB OTG and a more powerful processor at the expense of a little extra thickness and weight.

Again, not a bad tablet for the price, but there are other tablets available with better specs for the same money.  If this tablet were priced between $100 and $120, it would be a good deal.  At $150+, it's just too expensive for what you get.

input_doc:
VERY nice screen protectors at a VERY good price, but EXTREMELY difficult to put on without LOTS of bubbles! I had to keep lifting it up, like 14 times, and gently pushing the bubbles as I was lowering the protector before letting it lay flat, because once it's laid flat, you can't push/work the bubbles off to the edges like you can with most other ones. I got them for my granddaughter and she had asked me do it for her, because I am really good at it, have done them MANY times over the years and I have INCREDIBLE patience (and I like a PERFECT screen!). But I cannot see her being able to do these by herself, so I bought her some glass protectors, as they are MUCH easier to put on.
I am giving it 4 stars, though, because once I got it on, completely bubble-free, it looks and feels really nice! So if you are a person on a budget (3-Pack for $5.95!) with OODLES of patience, then these are the screen protectors for YOU!! If you frustrate easily....MOVE ON to another brand!! :)

input_doc:
Just got this today - seems very well built. It's a perfect fit for my HP M7 laptop in the main middle compartment. The rear compartment is supposed to be for folders with a divider in it but I use it to carry a small compact camera and a pair of headphones with room to spare. The front pocket is a bit small with a velcro closure flap and side zippers so it can open wide. Not a big fan of the velcro "RRRIP" sound, perhaps another zipper or clasp closer would have been nice - I can fit in a wireless trackball and the charger and cord and a Belkin surge protector plus a bunch of other small stuff. Might be a concern and I will have to keep an eye on it are the plastic D rings that the shoulder strap attaches to. They are sewn into the sides of the bag and held by a bit of strapping material that only appears to be stitched at that one point - the strapping material does not extend around the bottom of the bag as my older laptop bag had- which seemed a secure reinforced method of supporting the weight of a 17" laptop. The shoulder strap itself seems pretty sturdy and is attached to the D rings by carabiner-like connectors, also plastic that allow free rotation making it easy to untwist the shoulder strap if it ever does get twisted. Overall, it is nice and light, made of a textured fabric like material. I'll have to see how it holds up to daily use.
Update: the first day I used it, it felt good, nice and light. At end of day, with laptop all snug inside, I picked it up by the shoulder strap and slung it over my shoulder and started walking out to my car. After a few steps, the rear carabiner let go of its D ring and the bag dropped to the ground! I managed to grab the strap as it was falling and only the corner of the bag hit the concrete. Laptop is ok but I had to find out why that carabiner/hook let go. After fiddling with it for a few minutes, it is possible for this hook/carabiner to get positioned when the strap is hanging slack down and when the bag is lifted up by the strap, the springy metal part gets wedged against the d ring, and when weight is put on it, it releases and slips out of the d ring. I'll take a photo of how this can happen and add it here. Anyway, to keep this from happening again, I zip-tied the carabiner so the spring release can't open. But it was a scary moment when it released suddenly and may laptop was falling!

input_doc:
Nice motherboard with handy overclocking software. Only gripe is the cheap IO shield. A piece of it got lodged into a USB port and I didn't notice until I was waaay done building, so I had to cut it out. Half the fault goes to it being my first build, though. The XMP switch is handy as tinkering with OC settings took the RAM out of XMP mode occasionally.

Not a big issue, but I'm not a huge fan of the goofy little plastic caddy to make installing the CPU easy. I tried it for the heck of it, but needing to press the CPU into the caddy requires touching the bottom of it in some way, which you wouldn't need to do otherwise. It also adds some volume to the installation obviously, and the latch really creaked as I locked the processor in. Installed fine, but not a fun sound to hear! Just watch a youtube vid on installing CPU's and ditch the caddy.

input_doc: I was very excited to find a keyboard that had a trackball in the middle, just below the spacebar, to minimize arm/hand movement. input_doc: I don't know if I just got a "dud", but this machine crashed and went to blank screen either every day or every other day.  I was really disappointed as I had previously has an Acer for 10 years and was happy......not this time.  When I talked to the "help" line I was not very happy.  They wanted me to return the machine and I wouldn't have gotten it back for several weeks.  I ended up getting another machine and having to pay someone all over again to help me transfer all my information and fix up my desktop like I wanted.  All in all was NOT a good experience and I returned the computer for a refund.  I hope other people have had a better experience.  I wouldn't order a computer online again........nowhere to take it and get it back right away if something goes wrong.

I bought my ClamCase almost a year and a half. I was so excited to get my sturdy, multi-function ClamCase, and paid $149 plus shipping.

It is not a solid case, it cracked on two corners, it no longer looks whites but rather a beige or grey color, and the rubber corners have come off. I used it at home, watch Netflix, read, or research stuff. So I have never dropped it or had it fall onto the ground.  It cracked just from sometimes the Ipad snapping off the case.

I have rarely taken outside, and feel like I have taken good care of it.  And I have also rarely charged the keyboard. I have just gotten used to the Ipad keyboard. But now that I wanted to use the ClamCase keyboard, it will not charge.

I emailed ClamCase but to this day I have not heard from anyone.

So for $149 I feel like I just but a cover for my Ipad.  I wouldn't recommend it.  I should have spend less on an Ipad cover.  Lesson learned.

Don't buy it!!!

input_doc:
Quick update:  I have now been using this power cord for about 6 months (everyday), and it still works just as great as the day I received it! (original review Aug 2017; updated Feb 2018).

 I am SOOOOOOO happy I bought this new Adapter/charger!  Like others have already stated, one day out of nowhere my XPS 13 just stopped charging (and I would get an error message stating the AC Adapter wasn't recognized).  I read so many things online to try to find a fix, and nothing worked, until I got this.  Now I've only had it a few hours but this is the first time my computer has charged in over a month, so I'm very happy!  And i'm not sure why or how this adapter is different than the one that came with my laptop, but this cord seems to fit much better (my old chord used to fall out all the time, but so far, this one hasn't done that at all).

Maybe I just need to take it in, or maybe I have a defective one, but the processor on this thing is soooo slowwww.  Page loads on the internet browser feel like 28k dialup.

Apps and the internet unexpectedly quit on me more than half the time.  The keyboard function (when it decides to become available) rarely allows me to type a sentence correctly.  Cant run any video chat applications (skype, google hangout, etc) on this thing and expect to actually see anything better than a mosaic of whom your talking to.

I've only had this tablet for 3 months, and it's much more trouble than it's worth.

I'm betting you can find something just as, errr, 'good' for $50.

Here  is my problem and the service tech told me that this computer should not have external HDDs attached when booting.  This is an utterly stupid answer

I have a problem with booting my computer if I have more than four external drives on my 7 port hub. input_doc: Started really working out about 4 months ago, and realized just how much I sweat. Never really liked the cheap white earbuds that came with my ipod to begin with, but once I started working out I noticed they don't like sweat, cutting out, falling out, being uncomfortable, etc. So I thought I'd give these a try. Well worth the money. They sound great, way better then those tin can sounding, little, hard white things. They hold up to my sweaty workout routines, they fit nice, and come with different sized plastic dealies for different sized earholes (yea I said earhole). Very very fast and reliable drive. I purchased this to replace a mechanical Seagate in my mums all-in-one SONY VAIO which took 10 minutes to start-up as the hard drive was overheating in such a small enclosure. Even small tasks like opening skype were taking about 1 minute. The software included allowed me to clone the old drive onto the new SSD, which worked flawlessly and the PC is sooo much speedier at tasks and that awful constant whirring of the fans has stopped as it doesn't produce the heat of the old mechanical drive. A+

I bought a new $1,300 laptop.  The cover did not go on easily.  I pushed on it lightly to attach it to my brand new Yoga laptop, and the Yoga Screen Cracked.  Spent hours on the phone with Lenova to find out that the screen is not covered under the warranty.  It will now cost me $400-$500 to replace the screen on my two day old laptop.  Why would a product be offered that will crack a screen?  I am sooooooo upset.  My daughter now needs to start college without a new laptop because a screen takes 3 weeks to fix.

input_doc: This seems to be a reasonable ball head for the price if you stick to very lightweight cameras -- even more lightweight ones than the product specs suggest. Using the Giotto's 3/8 inch socket by taking out the 1/4 inch bushing, mounting this diminutive head on my Manfrotto 055XPROB Pro Tripod Legs (Black) gives me just barely under 2 turns of threading, which is solid enough for most point-n-shoots on this, admittedly, overkill tripod for such a purpose. Mounting the head to my Panasonic Lumix DMC-TZ4K 8.1MP Digital Camera with 10x Wide Angle MEGA Optical Image Stabilized Zoom (Black) gives me almost exactly 2 turns; to my Fujifilm Finepix F70EXR 10MP Super CCD Digital Camera with 10x Optical Dual Image Stabilized Zoom and 2.7 inch LCD, over 2 1/2 turns; and, in a pinch, to my Nikon D60 10.2MP Digital SLR Camera Black Gold Special Edition (Body Only), just over 2 1/4 turns. I have no idea how long the threads will last, but all of these connections are well within the sturdy range. My only negative observation is that the advertised load capacity for this ball head is overly optimistic: this is fine for point-n-shoots, but when I have grabbed this in a pinch for my Nikon D60 with a lightweight lens, the mount is anything but steady, even on the Manfrotto, even though the total weight of the camera, lens (a Nikon 50mm f/1.8D AF Nikkor Lens for Nikon Digital SLR Cameras, battery, card, and camera strap weigh in at ONLY 2lbs, 1oz -- less than HALF of the Giotto's advertised "load capacity" of 4.4lbs. It holds together, but just barely, and it's a bit wobbly. I know this product is not designed for a DSLR, but shouldn't any product perform steadily at _under half_ of its advertised load capacity? Just in the odd case that someone would consider getting this mount for the Manfrotto tripod mentioned above, I'd recommend against it -- the thumbscrew on the ball head is so close to the wide base of the ball-head mounting surface on the Manfrotto and is so short, that it's quite difficult to tighten. I haven't noticed that problem mounting the Giotto to quick-releases on cheaper tripods, though. My complaint is that the effective weight rating for this product appears to be under half of what it advertises.

input_doc:
I thought I'd edit this review now that I've had my drive for a while longer. The original review is below the line and still applies for while the drive is functional. The problem is this: These drives aren't actually particularly robust. What looks like a USB flash drive is actually a very small microSD card reader and a microSD card, encased completely in a plastic shell. The card reader part is the part that stops working (and when it does it basically just gives you a "you don't have permission to access this drive" error when you try to copy to it), so I was able to break the outer plastic case and remove the microSD card, which helped offset the loss of the drive a little. This seems to be a common problem with these drives, so be careful if you buy one.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
When I was looking for a usb drive I was trying to find the smallest one that had a decent amount of storage and was sufficiently durable. This excluded most of the the drives with moving parts (sliding or swiveling covers) and left this drive and two others on Amazon as possibilities. I'm very happy I ended up choosing this drive. It's pretty much as small as a usb drive can get (just the actual usb interface and about 1/4 inch beyond that) which is great for my purposes. I have it attached to my keyring and I didn't even notice any additional bulk when I attached it with the included little keyring leash. I've noticed some people have a little difficulty getting it out of their computer when I'm letting them borrow it but I haven't had any difficulties, so it's probably just an issue of having a tiny bit of practice. Overall I've had zero problems and highly recommend it.

input_doc:
I was able to pair the keyboard just fine, but the touch pad was nearly non-responsive (it didn't seem to matter how close I was to the device being controlled).  Often I would move my finger across the pad and the cursor wouldn't move, other times the cursor would just move seemingly randomly. The keyboard worked better, but some of the keys suffered from bounce, when you press a key once, the letter would appear multiple times. My application requires the touch pad to work properly so I had to return it as it just didn't work. Maybe I got a lemon, but other people have experienced the same issues so I'll look else where.

The form factor seems decent and I think I would have been reasonably satisfied if it has actually worked. I would prefer it just uses a couple of AAA's that are replaceable, the unit has a built in rechargeable battery which will certainly fail within 2-3 years, .

input_doc: I got this laptop last July from Circuit City and it is AMAZING!!! It works really well for what I use it for, Internet browsing, downloads, homework, and playing the sims 2. the buttons next to the power screen make it easy to bring up music right away, the wireless works really well and the battery power is somewhat reasonable (it still lasts about 2 hours on a full charge). in march i had to have the dc jack repaired, which took about 2 weeks, but it was under warranty so at least i didn't have to pay for it. it has a nice hard drive and i have plenty of space to store all my class assisgnments, photos, and videos. the webcam is a little gritty but it still works really well. one thing i don't really like is the speakers. they work well, but they are designed to basically collect dirt, and there is no real way to clean them. the keyboard is glossy and i love it, but it tends to collect a lot of lint. This is definitely worth an investment!! :)

input_doc:
The Samsung tablet I bought this case for is already a rare item in my country, so, I had to order the case from America. It is a replacement for another case I bought here in Colombia for pretty much the same price. However, The fintie case is way better. Waaaay better. It's sturdier despite its being smaller, my tablet turns on and off pretty quickly just by opening and closing the case, taking the s-pen in and out of the tablet is very comfortable, and working with an accesory keyboard is very comfortable when I fold the cover.

UPDATE: A month, and exactly as described by other customers, my case is already cracked on the corners despite a very light use. It is a good design in other aspects such as artwork, but it's totally ruined by a very poor choice of materials.

input_doc:
I had some problems with this item. I ordered it & shipped it to my box in the US, then I shipped it all the way to Riyadh - Saudi Arabia.
When I received the item it didn't start normally & it didn't have Windows installed!
I took it to Asus official support center & they discovered that the SSD was not installed properly & it was out of place!
Once they fixed it things worked normally & I finally felt glad I made this order.
The seller; Amazon, were really amazing & the refunded me 57% of the original price for all the trouble I went through.

Now that I've been using the laptop for the past 3 days, it's really REALLY the best laptop I've used so far..
Beats my previous MacBook Pro with ease.

input_doc:
I gave this product a 4/5 stars for overall performance, but I give it a 5/5 for the job I ask it to do: which is take notes in college classes.

It doesn't have a place to store my stylus (I knew that going in, but it'd be nice to have). It also doesn't have a battery gauge, so I can't tell where my battery life is. I haven't had any problems with it dying and previous review have it lasting a long while, but I do wish I could monitor the battery life. The bluetooth turns off if you haven't used it in a few minutes - which while I'm sure that's great for battery life, it's frustrating to feverishly take notes after a period of no activity because the bluetooth has turned off. The keys are also a little small, but I don't have much trouble typing quickly; it may be frustrating for writing papers or anything important.

Even with allllllll those negatives, they're really very minor in the grand scheme of things. I love the bluetooth so I can move the tablet or keyboard around independently of each other and the case is really nice and secure. Definitely a great investment for use in note taking/minor computer tasks, but probably wouldn't recommend for long term, intense use.

input_doc:
I bought this because I am a college student on the go. I Am always riding the bus for several hours and trying to keep my blog going was just horrible. I hated trying to type on my Ipad while on the bus because it would hit bumps and I would have to start all over. I only have a small budget to spend each month so I was going to get this more expensive version of this that I found at Best Buy at the end of the year when I have more saved up but found this for SOOOOO cheap and decided to go ahead and grab it.

I am so happy with it. I can write for hours, it fits perfect in my lap and it doesn't feel like it is going to fall off because of weight, I can write faster and update my blog more efficiently! The look is beautiful, the aluminum makes it so light to carry it around in my backpack that my back and shoulders don't hurt from carrying around my laptop anymore!  I am not going to get that one I saw at Best Buy, instead I will buy more ramen noodles and Red Bull!

input_doc:
I purchased this product due to Vaio reputation, I received the product and on initial boot up I noticed across the lower edge of the display LED backlight shining through, also light areas throughout the display, after that I noticed the speakers have a transistor radio like sound (tinny,treble) and there are no settings to change this, the F7 key was also crooked.  So I contacted Sony to get an RMA for replacement and! they wanted to set up an appointment for a repair technician to see if it could be fixed? This I consider very unacceptable for a product that is less than a few hours used. Support should have offered to send a new unit out with a return RMA tag prepaid shipping to replace the defective computer!!!  Instead I paid $32.00 out of pocket to have the unit returned for a fefund.

I feel that if the unit had no defects it would have been a great performer. Sony support is a complete let down!!

I am using it as I type this and couldn't have bought a more nice piece of gadgetry!! I learned on one of these and couldn't wait to have another and when the opportunity presented itself, I couldn't pass it up. It's comfortable, a tad bit on the big side, but all the features are PERFECT!! And everything is just as I had hoped for!! I looked at a couple of other good choices, but this one just seemed like it was the best fit for my work and myself. I would recommend this to ANYONE!!!! If anything should happen to this one, I have no problem buying this one again!!! LOVE IT!!!!!!!!

input_doc:
Nice keyboard, But missing lot of necessary features:

THe GOOD: PBT keycaps goodness( most keyboar come equipped with ABS),but these for 50 dollars have PBT caps...this is something that other popular manufacturer like Corsair, and RAZER need to do with all their keyboard..especially when they chagin hundred of dollars for their. With that said these caps kind of have thoes old  2014-2015 version razer keyboard weird rubber feel on the keycaps though, So it might be a fingerprint magnet overtime. RGB LED, look pretty nice with these caps, maybe it's just me. Run bluetooth 4.0..so wire is not really necessary. FEEL pretty premium for 50 dollars. plus Brown Switches...not as annoying as Blue, but are better than red IMO,[Not as smooth, but prefer tactile bumps, because it make my finger happy to type on them. ALSO, this keyboard is gonna be easy to clean.

THE BAD: No dedicated function media Keys, NO Battery Indicator Light, AND DOES NOT INCLUDE A BLUETOOTH ADAPTER WITH PURCHASE, and the 20 hours battery life? not sure on this.. have not fully test the hours.

Yeah it's a good buy, but it still missing lot of feature listed above...So, I think if you want another better one Try the ANNE PRO, it is around 70-80.dollars They do not have the dedicated media keys or arrow keys, but have the option on their mobile app to implement onto the keyboard...Which is what this keyboard really need, an mobil app. Still, I like this keyboard...I can't say the reason, maybe because the switches and the keycaps..Not sure.. Keeping it for typing, and possibly gaming purposes as well.

(Update) Nuuuuuuuuuu.... after a few weeks of constant use, the charging port became very wobbly, and now it won't even charged/work correctly when it's plugged in. media keys can be macro on mouse it was nice while it lasted.. the exterior is nicely build, but i guess it's the internal that need works. ALSO, the pbt keycaps will be fingerprint  magnets  after sometime,  and those print icon on  the front side of the keycaps will eventually decay, think it had already started on my. still is nice budget rgb bluetooth keyboard though for the price..but wait until it drop down to $50, not around 60. input_doc:
It took 6 months, 3 laptops and 30+ crashes to work out that these memory module are causing all of my problems. I kept moving from machine to machine thinking it was one of the other components, a faulty OS installations or broken platforms.

I tried using this in an a existing Windows 8.1 installation, a Mac OSX machine and finally installed on a fresh installation of Windows 10 until I realized this RAM module was the thing causing crashes in every machine.

It was also difficult to diagnose as sometimes my machine would last for days, maybe hours or maybe minutes and then just crash. I was unable to discern a real pattern in usage that caused the problem. The only trend I was able to work out was using this memory caused crashes. Unfortunately because it took me soo long to figure it out I can no longer return it....so BEWARE.

input_doc: I love this drive!!! I did a lot of research when replacing the hard drive in my Mac book Pro (this is the same year as the new retina display but is NOT the retina display model). I noticed an immediate increase in speed with this. Additionally I run parallels to have windows integration and the boot up speed vs the platter drive is very very noticeable. This is NOT the fastest drive out there (in fact the previous model is supposedly faster) however based on a lot of reviews and more extensive testing than I did, the battery usage on this is extremely low. While I say its not the fastest, its very fast but the battery savings on a laptop are well worth that trade off.

Last time I heard from a supervisor of the supervisor that I needed to fax the receipt for the purchase of the laptop in order to bring it to another supervisor to determine what to do. I still have not heard from them.

input_doc: Ive been needing one of these for a year now and they were just so expensive!!! And then I saw this one and it was such a great deal!!! And I can finally use my alarm clock I received last year for Christmas!!! Great product and even better price!!! Thanks so much!!!

Design flaws:
i) The trackpad makes a weird noise when you click. (Mac book doesn't)
ii) There is no option to make right click a primary click. This defies the whole purpose of having a clickable trackpad. (Mac book doesn't have this problem)
iii) I type a lot. My previous SONY VAIO was so nice to type on. It's difficult to type in this thing. (Mac book is so easy to type on)
iv) The fan vent is in a place which could be easily blocked if you prefer working on bed. (Mac book pro's vent is located in a place where it is impossible for someone to block it.)
v) No HDMI port. (Mac book does)
vi) The display could be better. (Mac book has such a crisp display)
vi) If your finger is wet, then it is hard to use the trackpad. (You can use macbook's trackpad even with a sweaty or wet hands)
vii) The lid doesn't have a good latch. It easily closes if your laptop is tilted. (Macbook pro's lid has a very good latch).

Things that I like:
i) Thin (Thinner than macbook pro)
ii) SSD
iii) Good speakers
iv) Cheaper than macbook pro but macbook pro delivers a well designed and a fine product with the price.  $1600 price tag on series 9 doesn't deliver the deserved and expected quality/design.

(I love macbook pro but I am not a fan of their "closed" OS and their price). So I had to chose a windows based laptop. Chrome book is small and their OS is kind of weird. Microsoft OS is old (Old is gold) and many programs are developed for windows machine. I chose series 9 with high expectation but was a little disappointed. input_doc:
Ok. I skimped and got the non-pro version. Fine. So many reviews out there saying that yu'll see so little difference between SSD models in real life, the *real* gain is over HDDs. This is what I observe...
[NOTE System is HP Pavilion DV6, i5 2410M processor (dual core with Turbo Boost tech), SandyBridge (i.e. SATA 3 compatible) with 8GB DDR3 PC3-10700 (2x4 GB) and now with this SSD 250 GB and Hitachi HDD 750 GB. Running Win 7 Home Proffesional 64]
1) Real easy to install, especially with the Magician Software provided by Samsung. Likewise you can firmware upgrade without having to wipe your system. Nice.
2) I also bought a USB 3.0 memory stick to go with the USB 3 ports that I have and transferring (large) files around is blisteringly quick now - like 150 MB/s quick (Lexar JumpDrive - awesome).
3) Benchmarking. The drive does what it says on the box. 500 MB/s read this and 250 MB/s write (large files). IOPS whatever it claims. All benchmarking tests seemed to show no lies in the product blurb.
4) REAL LIFE. I have done my background research, although I'm no computer expert. In Magician there is a secion to "Optimize your system for SSD usage" - disable "superfetch", disable "indexing", disable "defragmenter"... says AHCI should be enabled but that doesn't appear in my bios. All done. TRIM is enabled and free space is 50% to date of the drive. Junk files are cleaned regularly. And so I get to my point...
Solidworks, Photoshop CS3, IE9, Picasa 3.9, Left for Dead 2 (representative selection of what I have on my SSD) etc etc etc. None open blazingly quickly. A slight gain over a HDD, but then I did just reinstall Windows, that usually happens to me. Yes computer startup is quick now, maybe twice as quick, but again, a new Windows install is always quicker for me. Shut down still takes an age (WHY MICROSOFT WHY!?!!!!) Have I REALLY gained here? I'm just not sure I have, PERFORMANCE wise (file transfer-wise, yes).

Anyone got any tips for me? I am clearly seeing some SSD benefits, but am sorely missing others. Why isn't my CS3 opening SO SO fast like so many test sites claim? Why is shut down still a pain? How come I see such great benchmarks and file transfers and start up even when the aforementioned advntages are missing?

Any help would be greatfully received!!!

Summary. Inconclusive. Works, yes. Gains, yes. All the benefits that are "claimed" by SSD preachers... Yet to see. 3* or me...

input_doc:
Having had 2 very old hard drives, in different computers, die within 30 days of each other I find it hard to trust any hard drive especially since these are the old tech IDE drives and you don't get a lot of choices.
I did lose some data but most of my data had been backed up.
ALWAYS DO FREQUENT BACKUPS!!!
I will clone my drives with SATA USB external hard drives and have an adapter to be able to use it in my old computer along with frequent Document Files backups on another external HD.  This is much cheaper than building another computer when the current one works so well!
I also recommend you allow this HD its own power cord without sharing it.  I originally had it sharing power and the HD was not functioning properly after 3 months.

input_doc:
First, I'm not much of a TV guy, so I can't really rate the picture quality. To me it looks great, but I don't have much to compare it to.

I am however, an engineer who does embedded software development for a living. And that means that I recognize a firmware bug when I see one. And I've seen three after only about two weeks of usage. And that's with the latest available firmware as of 02/2010, version 1.08

We use this TV for two purposes:

1.) To connect our family computer to it (via HDMI) and enjoy the nice 1920x1080 resolution
2.) To watch some HDTV content which we receive via an outdoor antenna - using the built-in ATSC tuner.

Here are the problems so far:

1.) Whenever we switch to the PC (via HDMI) we can still hear sound from the TV channel. It's very faint, but it's audible - especially since we sit directly in front of the TV when using the PC. This is reproducable - not just a one-time event.

2.) Once, when watching ATSC TV, reception was poor and the TV went into a "loop" always repeating the last 3-5 seconds of video and sound - similar to an old vinyl record that skips... This stopped only when we changed the channel and then went back to the original channel. So far this only happened once, but it looks like the internal error handling for ATSC TV is not foolproof.

3.) When switching from HDMI (PC mode) to TV, we had no sound. Volume was turned on, but we heard nothing. Eventually we increased the volume to what would have been quite loud, and finally the sound came back - suddenly and loudly. We were than able to decrease the sound back to the regular range without it disappearing.

None of these are real serious problems, but they leave the impression that the firmware is still a bit immature...

I would have still rated it 4 stars, had it not been for Philips customer support who so far has sent me nothing but meaningless pre-canned replies when I alerted them to these problems....

At the end of the day though - we don't regret the purchase.

input_doc: When the case first arrive it was great and fit my tablet quite nicely....but after a week of using it the usb port to connect the keyboard to the tablet broke....I was very careful with this case and the USB still broke so I can't use the keyboard but it still does a great job at securing my tablet

I admit I was a bit leary after reading the reviews here. But with the features I wanted (video/audio in (for grandkids battery video games to use in the car), VCD, MP3 and JPG)plus a nice case I had to try this. Sooo I used it a lot in the first two weeks (daily one or more times). Used with battery and with AC. I recommend reading battery info at Cyberhomes web site, you cannot leave the battery in this unit for more than a day as it does drain because it powers the unit all the time even if it appears to be off (it powers the infrared receiver waiting for you to use the remote). -Read about Li-Ion batteries charging and discharging- You also need to remove the battery when using AC or Car adapter (they could have done a better job electronically here). Anyway, The picture is very good, even with having to adjust it's LCD mode for a regular TV picture as opposed to Wide Screen. Using the unit on battery and an external monitor/TV I got 3+ hours. Yes, I compared it to several other players, kept coming back to this ones abilities. My take, try one out, check reviews at other sites, if it breaks in the first couple weeks take it back to Target.

input_doc:
I adore the feel of this keyboard, as well as the look and form factor.  The keys feel nice, and while the lighting effects aren't necessary, I feel they do add something to this device.  I doubt I would use most of them, however, why wouldn't I want more lighting options?  if this was a wired Keyboard... I'd give it close to full marks.  The switches are satisfying, and seem like cherries to me...

However, I bought this thing to use with my Raspberry Pi via bluetooth.  The Pi connects and pairs to the keyboard, but I cannot get it to register any input.  Its annoying.  More annoying than this, is that I would love to reset the board so that it forgets all the paired devices and starts fresh. I have not found a way to do this... and re-pairing is an exercise in absolute futility.  I cannot for the life of me re-pair the device, despite following the instructions, which simply state that you hold FN+Q or W or E for 5 seconds.  First pairing seems to work, but after that, good luck.  The online manual states that you can hold 4 keys to reset the board but, this doesn't work. input_doc: Great computer since the day it was bought, buuuuuut one day I was watching tv on it as usual, then I had left it still on my bed to leave to the restroom, and when I had came back the screen had seemed like it went into sleep mode so obviously I attempted to awake the screen up by tapping on the mouse...after several attempts, the screen would not turn on.:( So with frustration I had shut it off and turned it back on and when the screen appeared to be on, the screen was still black. I moved around the mouse and then my mouse arrow appeared to look like it was from the first Microsoft update, it became big and less pixelated and along with that came the menu that also looked like it was from the first Microsoft era and was not helpful to me figuring out how and why to fix whatever happened, happened...and from my that day on, after going to multiple computer fixing stations (including the store I had bought it from -Best Buy-) , I was never able to use it again fuctionally... wouldnt recommend this computer to anyone:/ sorry

input_doc:
I got this to catch a problem neighbor trespassing outdoors.  I'm putting it up under my eaves.  I like the quality of the video even in very low light.  The onboard battery doesn't really last long so you need AC available and if you plug it in and can't get any video output reverse the red and yellow plugs on your tv---mine is switched someplace probably on the camera itself but it's no big problem because it works. You have to have a TV with RCA/F jacks to enter the setup of this unit. This thing is not cheap but it's about the cheapest unit of its type that you can find anyplace and some places charge a whole bunch more for this than amazon does.  This unit does not support SDHC only SD so your card is limited to 2 gig which is actually quite a lot of video recording.  You can plug this into your computer and windows sees it with the mass storage driver or you can pull the card out and plug it into any reader to play the videos; you can view files on a computer but you can't enter the setup except with a TV set.

I would have preferred they make it a little more weather resistant but those seemed to cost more.  This looks like a motion detector for a outdoor light, I'm going to hang it up under my eaves to watch my driveway area, it should be ok there and protected from the elements I just have to hope stupid doesn't figure out what it is and take the card out of it because it's pretty obvious what this is when you're up close to it.

input_doc: I just purchased this product for my Samsung SIII phone. The product sounds good, looks good and will easily fulfill my desire for a replacement for my clock radio. This unit is solid, sounds good (after learning to adjust both the phone and product volume). However, the application (from the instructions) and the newer replacement (found at the play store) were neither satisfying. They want to run all the time, docked or not, and do not find all the stations I want to play (uses TuneIn for radio). I found by removing these unneeded apps and just using an app from the play store (in my case, "CBS Local YourDay") which includes local radio (am&fm), news, sports, traffic and an alarm clock feature. input_doc:
ive had these speakers for a couple weeks now and i will say these are the best speakers for people who cant really afford high end amps,but still want clear and loud mid range sounds from four speakers.

let me explain in more detail i had the Pioneer TS-A6994R A-Series 6"x9" 5-Way 600 Watts with the Pioneer TS-A1684R A-Series 6 1/2" 4-Way 350 Watts they were powered by the Alpine MRP-F300 - Amplifier - V-Power - 4-channel. i had no clue how power hungry the pioneer 6 x9's were so of course my little alpine amp could not handle it and i couldn't afford a better 4 channel amp with more watts. and thus my music suffered because of it. and to top that the 6x9s had way too much bass because i already had a sub woofer in the back so it would sound weird sometimes were the bass would drown out allot of the voice.

With all that said i bought these speakers and yes they have little to no bass, this is a fact. but if you already have a sub woofer and a weak amp these speakers are amazing, the alpine amp matches perfectly with these speakers because they do not need much power, and due to the fact that they have little to no bass they hit the highs and mids pretty well.

my system sounds wayyyy and i repeat wayyyy better with these speakers, so if you have a sub woofer and a weak but high quality amp like the alpine i have these speakers are really the best and one the cheapest options out there.

P.S these puppies can take allot of damage as well like some other people are saying, i have put them on full blast for along time and they have not been blown or damaged in any way, great speakers for the money

input_doc: Here and there you read debates about whether the quality/design of a digital cable, going from source to DAC, makes a difference to the sound.  I was using a short Audioquest Forest toslink between the Auralic Aries Mini and my EMM DAC.  Even the local AQ dealer discouraged me from spending more money on the toslink.  I have a Wireworld USB cable that works very well, so the $200 multistrand borosillicate seems a fair bet.  No break-in period needed.  Simple comparison between two cables.  Obviously better soundstage, dynamic range and less vow-distortion (listening to Tori Amos Pretty Goood Year), clarity to instruments (much more distinct cello sound on that track) and bass.  Definitely a keeper, and, considering the difference in sound, this is a great bang-for-the-buck purchase.  Impact on sound is equipment dependent yes - if you know you have a good DAC with an excellent internal clock, this is likely going to be a rewarding upgrade.

input_doc: Ordered this case, edges cracked at about a weeks worth of use. I have never dropped it and only transport my laptop in a padded bag. Could not get it replaced because it was ordered during Holiday season. Shame on Amazon. Would never buy this case again. Defective product. Shame on Speck. Do not waste your money!!!!

It looks very nice, but I couldn't get the wifi to work. All my other devices (3 laptops, 4 phones, 1 ipad) can access the internet with no issues. I didn't want to deal with Dell support and decided to return it. I bought a Lenovo to replace it. Had the same problem but connected to Lenovo tech support immediately!!! Zero wait time! It turns out I had to download the new wifi driver software from my other laptop to a USB drive and then copy the driver sw to my new laptop. These new laptops don't come with LAN ports anymore. The wifi worked once the new driver was installed.

input_doc: Works great and was able to use with my HP Steam/8.1 laptop. I did have to download a DVD player drive from a 3rd party but it works amazing! Great for the price!!!!

This was bought as a birthday present in November 2010.  Right away after opening the package I had issues with the Trio T3000.  I like the touch screen interface, although sometimes it does not respond when scrolling up or down.  I put a screen protector for a cell phone on the product to protect the touch screen. The player sometimes shuts off unexpectedly, and then won't turn on until you connect it the the USB port on the computer to "reset" it.  By "reset" I mean leaving it on to charge 2 to 4 hours and then not turning it off until I'm done listening to it because it may not come on again.  The unit that I have has stopped working as of 2/13/2011, so I got a little over 3 months of use before it quit on me.  The good news is the warranty is one year, so I'll call tech support at 580-272-0035 and have it replaced.  I'll give an update on the new unit, if the new unit does the same thing I would recommend not buy this product.  The file formats that I used were WMA, MP3.  I didn't try to use the video or camera abilities of the product.

input_doc: This laptop was working fine for a couple of months. Then it started to get slower and slower. Then after a while it will turn on but no display.  Do not buy!!!

I just unboxed it and it installed flawlessly in my computer.
It comes with a USB power adaptor to power the card, if necessary.

It worked fine with a Iphone 4s that I installed and charged it.

Than I decided to connect a 8 port USB 2 Hub to it with multiple devices and
a Microsoft LifeCam Camera. Other devices ran fine.

The camera was very flickery. I decided to reboot my machine and while closing down saw the
dreaded BSOD. Rebooted and camera still ran flickery.

I searched the internet for updated drivers and ran across this site station-drivers.com/page/renesas.
for drivers, t add the [...] and the www to it and at the end a htm

But I couldn't figure out how to update the driver. The camera is a known problem.
I'll be happy if I can hook a USB 3 device or hub to it and realize faster speeds. I can always directly plug the camera into the
computer.
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
I'll be doing a backup directly with a USB drive and time the speeds and see if it's stable.

input_doc:
I wanted to love the Tablo but ultimately I returned it.  TIP: I wasted an hour on incorrect directions in the packaging.  It says in the quick setup to connect a hard drive, connect (wired) to the network and then connect to power.  It then instructs you to locate Tablo on your WIFI network to connect and configure.  HERE IS WHAT IS WRONG - if you connect the Tablo unit to the network via a network cable Tablo will turn off its internal WIFI.  This means it will NEVER display on your WIFI network and you can't configure the Tablo unit as instructed.  SOOOO.... don't connect Tablo to your network via a network cable when you are first setting it up!  Or alternatively use a Windows computer, running Chrome web browser to find and configure the Tablo unit if it is connected via Internet cable to your network (that is how I found it - not via WIFI).

The Good: It has a first rate program menu and interface.  It's worth $5/month for it.  It is easy to setup and configure (except for the tip I posted as first).  It does a good job reliably recording shows.  (With good WIFI signal strength) It streams shows well to my tablets and Windows 7 laptop.

Why I Returned It: The Tablo App is not ready for prime time.  As is, the App is good for watching recorded Tablo shows on your android tablet BUT is horrible at projecting it via Chromecast to your TV.  It lags, its buggy and it's prone to crashing.  With my laptop, it works well with Chromecast BUT I didn't buy this to have my laptop sitting on my lap to watch TV.  If that were the case I'd simply plug in an HDMI cable and stream the shows from the TV channel sites.

THEY ARE SOOOOO CLOSE... but not there yet.  Compare their app's chromecast capabilities to Netflix or Huluplus and you'll understand how far behind they are.  NOTE this was in Nov 2014 that I had used the unit and app.  Maybe it's been improved by the time you read this.

**Rationale for Consolidation:**
- **Aspect Term & Opinion Term:** All agents agreed on the key aspect terms and related opinion terms, ensuring consistency.
- **Sentiment Polarity:** There was broad agreement on the sentiment polarity for each aspect term; any differences were minor or isolated to single agent interpretations.
- **Sentiment Intensity Score:** Where there was a discrepancy (e.g., scores of 3 vs. 4 for 'product'), a median score or the most common score was chosen, aligning with the overall positive sentiment.
- **Category Assignment:** The final categories were determined based on majority agreement or clearer term alignment in the document context. For instance, 'Bluetooth capability' aligns with 'multimedia_devices connectivity' as supported by the consensus in agent outputs.

input_doc:
Even at the brightest setting, this screen is 25% dimmer than the Hp 2133.  Also note that it comes with IE6 installed, and the unusual screen size re the weird driver setup causes some web pages to go bonkers (huge text).  Going to IE7 or Firefox solves this.

The keyboard is almost unusable, of course.

The Pros are the small size and weight.

See my review of the Hp 2133 and the critical problem it has with the Via chipset.

My conclusion, this machine is, for a secondary, going to meeting type of machine, the better of the two.  If HP changes the VIA to an Intel chip, there is absolutely no question that the ASUS would be inferior.  Note, however, that the ASUS does OK on its 4 cell...and the HP is somewhat bigger and about 60% heavier (the souped up model is well over 3 lbs, despite the adverts).

<<<<<< Update June 7 >>>>>>

Asus has just demonstrated the eee PC 1000.  It has 7 hours of battery life, a larger keyboard, and is about 1.75 inches wider.

input_doc:
Bought this Laptop from BstBuy for under $480 including tax,,,,

It is a bit heavy than currently available laptops, but it is okay because it has metal body, and it really looks good quality and premium design, it looks different and really good as compare to other laptops available under $600...

Graphics and performance is really good,, I did play "Battlefield 3" on full HD with high graphics on, but still it don't get hot, but lil bit over warm and very quite cooling fan, So I guess I don't need to explain anything else regarding performance.

"beats audio" is too overrated, my old compaq cq50 sounds way laud and clear than new HP with beats audio.

USB 3.0 works fine, way faster than usb2.0...
Fingerprint reader doesn't work for me (usually too much sweat on my fingers, sometimes it works and it has cool feature, you can register fingerprint and use it to login your emails without typing username and password.

Have to get use to of this kind of keypad and touchpad,,,, its not at all bad but old one is really good, so it will take some time to get used to it.. multitouch is not so good as windows does not have good software to work with that but still sometime it is useful....

battery life duration changes depends on how you use it,,, but runs longer than 3 hours on full charge on average/mid settings..

overall, it is a good one, no regrets,,, so many of my friend who spent more than $700, they can not believe that this one is under $500 (because it looks premium quality and performs good too)

Have used for 1 month and it more than meets expectations.  Back light is very good, although I would like a brighter light setting.  OK for typing emails, but might not meet expectations for very rapid typing.  Quiet, soft touch keys.

Boooo to Amazon on crappy packing.  The shipping box was twice the size of the keyboard box, and contained no bubble wrap or peanuts, only one piece of folded up paper.  I couldn't believe how poorly this was packed for shipping.  I guess that speaks to the quality of the keyboard, which is heavy and solid. The selected categories reflect a consensus when possible, with compromise based on the preponderance of evidence from the various agents' analyses.

input_doc: I bought it for my 2012 Macbook Pro.  It came with the 5400 rpm hard drive. input_doc:
So far so good.

Bigger than I expected but pleasing to the eye, durable and fast to boot.

Best part of all for those on a budget like myself was the low price.

Highly recommend it!!!

The sound from the radio is good. Is it awe inspiring? Not remotely.  The Bose system is waaaay over-priced for what you get. Further, Bose represents that this system offers the opportunity to listen to the radio over the Internet. Do not believe it. We have never been able to connect to any other radio station other than local stations.

Also, customer support comes from the Philippines; it is frustratingly useless. Absolutely time-wasted uselessness.

input_doc: For a pinpoint stylus, it's alright i guess. Sometimes it doesn't register on my ASUS TP500LA Touchscreen laptop when I am trying to scroll or hit buttons. That can become annoying for someone that is trying to work fast. But it works fantastically on my Sony Xperia Z Ultra Smartphone. The nib also sort of sticks on the glass of my laptop and can make it difficult to draw notes in OneNote. I have been using a hard nib point, I haven't tried the soft nib point, so my experience might be completely different if I was using a soft nib. Also, the auto-off feature after like 20-30 minutes can be irritating if you plan to have it on while sitting in a meeting or class. I think you can get past it by clicking the power button every now and then, but that hasn't been proven by me yet.  BUT! The pen is rechargeable via microUSB, which is FANTASTIC! No AAAA batteries that you have to replace every week or so. Also, when its not missing recognition, it is very accurate, which I can't say the same using your finger or a broad tip stylus. I got this pen cheaper on another website, which was a better price than what they are selling it here. So if you can find it cheaper, I would recommend it.

Ok,  first off, the price is not cheap but it is OK if I did not find below problems.
2nd, I did not take a star away because I can deal with the set up. Their software is not that easy to maneuver you may need to call customer service for help unless you are a computer geek. Besides their customer service is based in the Philippines and it's kind of difficult to understand because of their accents.
3rd, DLink customer service acknowledged that they have problem with its 4G connectivity, meaning YOU CAN ONLY VIEW FREEZE PICTURE AND NOT VIDEO. I tried everything and it is NIL.  They said they are working on the 4G problems but since last year? Hmmmm  So, that's taken one star away.
4th, if you try to monitor outside activity from behind a window. It is OK if during daylight but not at a dark environment because infrared lights will reflect on the glass and gives you the glares that completely not viewable. input_doc:
MBP users should know that while this product is a perfect size for the 15" model and it definitely keeps your laptop cooler, there is an issue.  The design of the USB connection has the cord attached at the back.  In order to make sure that it doesn't block your power connection, you must bend the USB cord waaay down.  There is still danger of your power connection not being completely in contact as it should be.  Also, with the short length of the coolpad's USB power connector, there isn't an option to plug it in on the other side of your MBP.

O, and if you plan to use this on your lap, look first at the contours of the bottom.  Although the large feet make a great base on a hard surface, you may want to use a lapboard or something similar between the plastic edges of the bottom surface and your legs.

Even with the minor issues (after fiddling with it a bit and getting things settled in) I am very happy with this product. It does the trick with my MBP, even when I play WoW.

input_doc: Sorry guys, as you are all top reviewers maybe mine was a lemon.  The viewing angle...  Holding it straight on (as its intended to be used) watching anything (netflix) I basically got a pencil drawing.  NO color, just black and gray outlines. Just too bad if I wanted to pick it up and use  it as a tablet the picture disappears.  The speakers were tinny and junky, no surprise there. input_doc:
According to our sales man, this camera was rated by Consumer Reports as the Number 1 Camera under $....  Two weeks after purchasing it, I failed to see why.  The limited 2 Megapixels DO make a difference, especially when printing regardless of size.
Features I liked: Nightime flash was wonderful!  Looked like photos were taken during the day.  Very lightweight (although almost seemed flimsy).  Superior Lens Quality.  Picture Size: even high quality photos were not huge in bytes on the computer.
Features I did not like: Cannot View Photos (or even last photo taken) without shutting camera.  Prolonged time from taking of one photo to next (I am talking 20-40 seconds! a lot when you see a photo you like).  Often "closed" the front panel when grabbing camera from someone to take a photo, in turn shutting it off.  Red Eye feature: everyone always blinked after it.
In the end, I exchanged it for the D-550 which was much worse (stay away!) and finally got the Sony CyberShots.

Great router. It is dual band, has great features and looks nice.

Lets see, setup is fast, I am advanced user so didn't use the wizzard.

As a router it probably works great. I am however using it as an AP at this time, which is the few bugs I found.

First one is in AP mode you cant set timezone, so set that while in router mode, than put in AP mode. Also in AP mode static IP does not seem to stick all the time jumping back and forth between DHCP and that. For most people not a big deal.

I cant say if it will have issues in router mode as no need for me to use that mode.

My only physical complaint on it is the stand. Wish I could put it the other way as I have a shelf on a wall for it and it sits backwards now.

Speed wise, its FAST.

I was able to transfer at over 19MB/sec from Wifi to a LAN computer and while doing so got full internet speeds and had no problem getting onto router still.

This is a new product so some bugs are expected but the ones I found are minor and should be fixed easy by manufacture, and only seem to be on the AP mode.

***Update 9/18

Just thought I would add I am running a beta firmware .19 they just released and it has not helped in AP mode. I have also learned the 2.4Ghz mode can't keep active connections to devices. The 5Ghz seems fine but found this out the hard way as my xbox is useless.

Netgear support is horrible as always when trying to contact them. It's sad. They have some GREAT employees but the front line is just a mess.

Anyway I have ordered the WNDR4500 and will see if its any better. If it gets here before this one has working FW this goes back. I should also note the 5Ghz range is about 1/5th of the 2.4. It is normal to be less, about half (due to higher freq), but not 1/5th.

**Update 9/23
Still no help from netgear, and a good number of people on forum with issues also.

I now have a WNDR4500 in hand which seems to run better however its got its own issues on the 2.4GHz band it seems also, poor speed and connection, but at least stable and 5GHz is way better vs 3800. I don't see how they release 2 bad products in a row. Most of these issues are with basic usage and should have been caught during testing :(

input_doc:
I bought this router primarily for its GB LAN support because of some NAS I have connected to a four-drop hardwired network within the house. It has provided excellent security protection and total reliability.

As we all know, it is nearly impossible to determine where the weak link is in a "Wireless Network". There are sooooo many things that can affect signal-strength/range.

That being said, I have had this box for more than a year. In-that-period of time, numerous different wireless network cards in numerous different LapTops/DeskTops have tried to connect, and none of them can sustain an "Excellent" signal-strength no matter where they are positioned, and most of the house can't be reached reliably at all. I have tried moving the router but I am limited as to where I can go with it.

So far the wireless applications have not been a major handicap as I have sufficient numbers of wired workstations, but it dose eliminate some of the flexibility.

Obviously, I am disappointed in the Wireless performance, but ALL other aspects of the device I love.

input_doc:
When I initially bought this and started using it I thought it was the best thing since sliced bread. But then it got progressively worse from there. I will do cons and then pros if that's ok?

Cons:
Polaris Office - Failed on me several times, why include it if it doesn't work? There is no support for this application either.
Apps - There is no Android support mechanism that I can see. What do you do if there something wrong? Think about this. If you buy something in a store you can return it. Can you return an App???
Skype - Fails to work. Causes issues with Skype on my other devices.
Speakers - Very poor sound from the speakers. My phone has better sound. You will need earphones unless you are in a cave.
Marketplace - You can ONLY buy videos from Google. Therefore you can only buy from their collection which has no TV episodes. Surely there is a Competition and Monopolies Commission that can do something about this? Didn't they do this and sue Microsoft back in the day?
Videos - I bought two videos to watch on a plane. I started watching one and then decided I would watch the rest later. It will not play for me no matter what. So, I decided I would try the second video. Just to be cruel to myself I paused and went out of the Video app to look at another app and when I came back this second video would not play either. Gave an error eventually.
Keyboard* - The keyboard, sold seperately, has to be the worst designed piece of hardware I have ever come across. The spacebar is too close to the mousepad which is far too sensitive. If you are typing and the heel of your hand brushes off it expect to see your text somewhere else on the page.

Pros:
Design - Physically this is lightweight and slick. The concept of allowing a keyboard attachment is great but in practice fails.
Battery - Seems to be really good.
Software - Android is ok. Unfortunately they seem to accept mediocrity. In the long run I can see them failing as either Apple, Microsoft or some unknown will blitz them if they allow higher sales at the expense of mediocrity.
Browser - Pretty good. Some sites don't translate well. Anything that needs an internal move of the mouse such as a cursor bar will not work well or at all. Would be nice if the browser ranked bookmarks in order of most use.
Supernote - This is really good. I used it a conference to takes notes instead of using a pen and paper.

Overall I made the mistake of not understanding exactly what I would use it for and then testing each application. But who has time to do that?

input_doc: This so far has fulfilled all my expectation. I bought this from the Alienware website so I can get it personalized, I went with the fully-loaded one, 16 gb of RAM, i7, blue-ray, 2TB, windows 8, ect... Im also using this as a media center, I have it plugged to the TV and also my monitor, so when I want to watch a movie or play Black ops with a controller it will be on my 46in tv, and when I want to play some Starcraft or ect.. it will be on my monitor with the keyboard and mouse, also the monitor and keyboard is not close to the TV and where I have the x51, but VGA and USB extension does the trick. OH! Black Ops 2 works sooo nice, the graphics looks ALOT better than on PS3, and x51 also looks realllly nice and its not very big, I barely use it as a PC... I saw bunch of people complaining about the wi-fi on this and I can say, the wi-fi may be the weakest point of this system, thats not to say its bad because I don't have a problem with it, but I did notice it wasn't picking up all the wi-fi my apple, or other laptops we're picking up. input_doc: Bought this for my son who is 19 and it far exceeded my expections!! I wished it would of arrived by xmas but it still came a day earlier than expected arrival date I was given! The pictures do not do it justice!! I'm beyond happy with my purchase and son is on cloud nine! I'm not even a gamer but this makes me want one! I'd Def buy another! It was shipped very nicely and had everything it said it would! If your considering a new gaming computer, buy this one it is fabulous!!!!!

Fastest Laptop I have ever owned. Downgraded and installed Windows 7 (it came with Windows 8.1). After a little tweaking here and there I get the password screen in 9 seconds from the time I hit the power button. Incredibly fast - Best before was on a desktop I built (with an SSD) and that was 21 seconds. I attribute this to the Intel i7 processor, 16GB of RAM, but most of all that I removed the HDD and replaced with a Crucial 512GB SSD. Put about a dozen services on delayed startup. The ONLY reason I deducted a star is because the numeric keys on the keyboard are sooooo small. However, if you plan on using the laptop with 2 external monitors and a full size keyboard, that won't matter anyway.

I wanted a reliable laptop to replace my Dell's (which are garbage  - have gone through 3 of them - defective hardrives) as well as the HP's we had before that.

I read good reviews for this one online.  Right out to the box it failed.  Called ASUS - they said I need to ship it back to them to repair.

The great thing about AMAZON is instead I'll return to them for a full refund and buy something else.

Is there a reliable PC out there???? Something that will last more than a year without crashing?  No more Dells, HP's and now ASUS - all garbage!  Maybe I'll break down an buy an Apple  - they just aren't compatible w/ anything for necessary for work, unless you buy all new software.

input_doc:
We live in a basement apartment, and the internet comes in from one end of the house. My office is on the other end, and I was really struggling keeping a solid signal to my wireless router. I got this repeater to try to extend that range, while still maintaining as much of my internet speeds as possible. Here are my results:

***All speeds were clocked using SpeetTest.net on the same computer***
Speed I pay for: 50 Mbps

-WITHOUT THE REPEATER-
Speed in room of router: 60 Mbps down / 12 Mbps up
Speed in office (across house): 22 Mbps / 11 Mbps up

-WITH THE REPEATER HALFWAY BETWEEN ROUTER & OFFICE-
Speed in office (across house): 3 Mbps down / 5 Mbps up

-WITH THE REPEATER IN THE SAME ROOM AS ROUTER-
Speed in room of router/repeater: 22 Mbps down / 12 Mbps up

Overall, the repeater did help extend my network, but it reduced my download & upload speeds drastically. So if you are okay with reduced download speeds or you are looking for something to extend your upload range, this might be a good choice for you. For me, I was hoping to get the full 50 Mbps in my office since the unit claims to be able to transfer 300 Mbps, but that just did not hold true.

One last note: The repeater does look like it covers both outlets, but if you use it on the upper outlet the lower outlet is still accessible for a normal-sized plug (a wall-wart would not fit)

input_doc: I'm typing on my PROfolio+, which is a present to myself, even as I write this review.  I'm a touch typist and this is soooo much easier and faster than using the iPad's keyboard on the screen.  Plus, I have more screen space, since the keyboard no longer pops up, whenever I type.  I've been using it for over six weeks, for at least a few minutes every evening (sometimes much longer) and have yet to have to recharge the keyboard.  It's nice to have the backlighting, in case I want to type in dim light or even in the dark.  Even though the keyboard can only be propped up at one angle, I haven't found that to be a problem. This is not the thinnest keyboard, but I like that it has the same feel and feedback as my laptop's full size keyboard, even though it doesn't have a built-in 10-key pad. The keys are nicely spaced apart and I was typing fast in no time. I would've liked it if I could turn the iPad vertically (into portrait mode) for apps that on work in portrait mode, but that hasn't been a very big problem, because the apps I use and type in, they auto rotate to landscape mode. input_doc: Everything in the description said it would work for my MacBook Pro 13in Mid-2012 but that was a lie. When I went to install the hard drive I noticed the casing wasn't the right fit. After I contacted customer service, I tried to install it because I was assured that it wouldn't matter. Once I installed it and booted up my mac, I spent hours gettting my computer to be able to be able to recognize the new hard drive. The first time I closed my MacBook and turned it to its side, the hard drive broke in two pieces. Thanks HGST. You're the best

I had high hopes, as my other adapters don't have the convenient 90 turn. This adapter two-pack was packaged nicely, and the plastic feels sturdy and durable.

*However* they will not work in either of my devices with 3.5 millimeter ports (a MacBook Pro and an audio interface). The toslink side was a tight fit, but seemed okay. On the other end though, the adapters are not correctly sized as required for 3.5mm plugs. As seen in my photos:
 A typical female 3.5mm jack is up to 0.1mm oversized, to accommodate slight plug variations.
 A typical male 3.5mm analog TRS plug is up to 0.1mm undersized, to always fit easily.
 These adapters waaay exceed the tolerance range, however, and in the wrong direction! Rather than perhaps being slightly undersized to always fit, they are instead oversizedby almost 0.15mm. I could not get them to plug in even halfway into either of my devices; they physically will not fit.

input_doc: I bought this computer Gateway NV57H50U Laptop / Intel Celeron B800/ 15.6" Display / 2GB Memory - Black about 3 days ago and I love it!!! It's waaaaaay better than the old Dell (2007) that I already had. This laptop is pretty entry level but it has ALL the bells & whistles necessary for today's modern society. BTW, I only paid $279 at Best buy. The speed is excellent in comparison to my 60GB Hard drive Dell, but I will be upgrading the RAM to 8GB as well as another customer said. Mine isn't "laggy" as they put it, but hey, why not! It has a dedicated number pad (which I totally love) and it also has an HDMI port which is perfect when u download a movie and you don't want to wait for it to burn! Hope this review helps someone.

input_doc:
I had decided to use my smartphone's (Galaxy S) Google Maps as my primary navigation tool a few months ago and I went back to a standalone GPS unit after experiencing problems with the spotty AT&T network connectivity and a weak GPS receiver on the phone.

I'd been using an older Garmin 4.3 incher for several years and the 1450LMT is very similar to the older model. No complaints there -- the interface is simple (QWERTY keyboard is much better!), the touch sensitivity has increased, and the 5-inch form factor is large and readable. Why fix something if it ain't broke?

pros: lifetime maps update, traffic rerouting / guidance, qwerty keyboard input
cons: slooow update process, no error-correction/suggestion with names (compared to a smartphone)

The output integrates and reconciles the findings from the LLM agents, presenting a clear aspect-oriented sentiment analysis.
