input_doc:
These headphones are beautiful and they sound very nice. Not as nice as my Sony MDR-SA5000s, but very nice nonetheless.

These are portable headphones (they fold into a carrying case) so they are not going to sound as good as a pair of full size studio headphones with bigger drivers.

They have some nice features, three different cables, one plain and two with mic and headset controls, one universal and one apple.

The apple cable works perfectly with a macbook or an iphone.

The carrying case is nice too.

Now, the problem I have with them:

I have big ears and a slightly big head, and if I leave these headphones on for a couple of hours my ears start to hurt pretty badly. This is because the ear cups are small and the headband is very tight and made of a very unyielding material.

Maybe this was done to improve sound isolation, I don't know, but for me it totally sucks.

I only bought these because I needed an emergency pair of headphones for work and my sonys got sent out for out-of-warranty repair, and these are the best reviewed headphones I could find at a certain retailer that will go unnamed.

I am eagerly awaiting the return of my sonys as my primary headphones at work.

I will probably either keep these for portable use, like when going on a trip, or I will give them to someone as a gift, someone for whom they would be a better fit.

input_doc: Do not waste your money. The chrome os is not compatable with the rest of the world. You cannot open anything that uses microsoft, wich is most of the world. If all you are going to do is surf the web is fine, but if you have school work you will not be able to open files, or your teacher will not be able to open yours. BUY SOMETHING ELSE!!!!!!!!!

Works well for me.  But, as someone else stated, the keyboard has alt functions that you can't see because of the blue lettering on the black keys. I use this with windows and I wish it had a right mouse button as well as an escape key on the front, somewhere.  Probably better suited to Android users, but it does work okay for me.

after 2 mos,,,I am learning more,,,humidity seems to be hurting camera quality,,by displaying a "no image " signal,,,
  distant vision is unclear,,(beyond 50ft...
The frequency of the unit disrupts my laptop,,,and my TV antenna...
A less costly security system..but Defender had a good review...
I have the 2 cameras,, both mounted outside...
  nite vision... does a good job...I can see out to the street,,and houses across the street...but it is not "sharp" at distance...
behind glass,,when ,mounted inside,,,there is no nite vision,,,for some reason..

  Audio... is there if you want it,,,picks up the noise at the camera,,,if you want to hear it,,,
  Electrical....each camera requires an outlet,,also the monitor..Using the RCA cable(supplied),the can be plugged into a TV...

mounted on the outside,,the bad guy could unplug the camera....

```json
            "I ordered two of them and by the time I used them it was too late to return them....absolute garbage...DO NOT BUY."
        ],
        "aspect_term": "return process",
        "opinion_term": [
            "too late to return"
        ],
        "sentiment_polarity": "negative",
        "sentiment_intensity_score": -2,
        "category": "shipping operation_performance"
    }
]
```

**Final Conclusion:**

1. **Aspect Term Identification**: 
   - Agents identified "reviews," "battery," "return," and related terms like "product" and "return process" as explicit aspects.

2. **Aspect Categorization**: 
   - "Reviews" fit best under "out_of_scope general" because it's more about regret over ignoring reviews.
   - "Battery" is consistently categorized as "battery operation_performance."
   - "Product" was mapped to "company quality" because of overall product dissatisfaction, aligning with the term "absolute garbage."
   - Differences on "return" focus were reconciled, categorizing it under both "shipping operation_performance" and "company quality" based on context.

3. **Opinion Term Extraction**: 
   - Opinion terms about battery operation were straightforward: "lasts about 10 minutes," "does not re-charge."
   - "Absolute garbage" and "DO NOT BUY" were consistently noted as strong negative sentiments about the overall product.
   - "Too late to return" was cited as a negative sentiment about the return process.

4. **Sentiment Polarity**: 
   - All identified aspects were consistently negative across agents.

5. **Sentiment Intensity Score**: 
   - Scores aligned across most aspects, assigning high negative intensity (-5) to product quality complaints due to overall strong dissatisfaction expressed. 
   - Battery issues were consistently marked as -3 due to moderate dissatisfaction with performance, while returns got a moderate score of -2 reflecting late-process frustration.

input_doc: Ok so I have a 64bit Windows 7 HP laptop with a built in Atheros wifi adapter and never really had any problems with it until I rented a room out from some people who live in a 2 story house and the wireless modem upstairs. I previously gave this adapter a bad review but it was a mistake. I do not know what happened and maybe it just needed to be broken in but this adapter all of a sudden started working waaaayyyy better. It now picks up many connections that my other adapter cannot see and the reception is much better. I was ready to RMA this thing but for the passed couple of days it changed. Maybe it is psychic and knew I was gonna return it so it had a change of heart? lol jk but this product is amazing and has saved me a lot of trouble. So if you are someone with a similar OS as mine and a similar situation where the modem is a floor up and out then this will solve your problems but you may have to break it in I guess. I had originally gave it 2 stars because when I first plugged it in it was only picking up 2 networks whereas my other card was picking up 5 almost 6 and my connection problems were still bad but just before I was about to return it I turned on my computer and it is now picking up 10 to 12 networks and the reception has shot up and I didn't update the driver it is the one that comes on the disc so you might have to give it some time to work  I guess?

The battery/card compartment wants to unlatch, be aware that when you do open it the battery latch is probably going to open as well and dump your battery on the floor. input_doc:
I gave this product 3 star based on the Pros & Cons as stated below:

Pros:
- Downloadable software from intel website to schedule trimming for SSD optimizing.
- Downloadable software from intel website for cloning purpose.
- Comes with a Sata III cable.
- Comes with 5 screws that could be used in securing the SSD to HDD Bay in Desktop.

Cons:
- Software does not have a benchmark to tell how much read and write your system perform.
- (major) Does not detect as a SSD in older laptop (tested with Samsung Evo Pro which could reflect in the BIOS of older laptop).

Overall:
I bought it with the intention of reviving my older laptop which is around 5-6 years old but to my dismay, it could not detect in the BIOS of the system. So i tested my laptop with a Samsung Evo Pro which return a positive test result instead.

As the title describes, I put this bad boy in my February 2011 17" MacBook Pro, and WOW! So glad I did. I had wanted to swap out my HDD for an SSD for quite some time, and honestly, I was blown away by the performance upgrade. Srsly...this was a HUMONGOUS improvement in speed and performance, couldn't be happier, and Amazon has a great price with Prime shipping.

I just Googled instructions on how to install the drive, and it was very simple. One think I would note, for those who are less experienced with computers, when you take out the old drive in your MacBook, make sure you unscrew the small metal screws in the drive, and screw them into the m4 SSD. That will secure the drive in your MacBook.

Highly recommended!!!

input_doc: These are a good way to keep your safety officer off your back but you have to compromise on sound quality. They sound a little better than listening to songs over a phone but not by much. For talk radio they are perfect, though. And really if you work at a factory like I do you are just happy to be able to listen to anything besides the machines around you so in that sense they are definately worth the $15.00. input_doc: I received my 70" Vizio on Monday.  I was a bit concerned after reading a review about the Amazon delivery service but my TV arrived before 8 AM!  It was quick to set up and I started to enjoy it right away.  I have to say the picture on this set is absolutely amazing!!  I am coming from a 60" Sony DLP set and that TV was great but the new LED technology makes the colors so vivid and bright.  I have also watched a few 3D movies and again I am in shock at how stunning the picture is.  I will agree with some complaints about the reflective screen as it is very reflective; however, I enjoy watching TV in the dark so it doesn't bother me.  I am not experiencing any light bleed so that isn't an issue for me either.  The remote is a bit slow but I use my Xfinity universal remote and only need the TV remote when I'm switching to 3D or using a smart app (which I tend to do through my xBox so I rarely need the ones built into the TV).  Again I am absolutely in love with my TV and now I am leaving work to go home to it!!!  :)

input_doc:
This is the 2nd Mac that I have had after my Powerbook G4.

I had the B model and got this one because of the Nvidia Card and I am soooo satisfied!

If one thing I have learned about these machines is that they hold up very well to wear and tear.

There isn't too much more that  I can say that everyone else has said already except that for what you spend you get top notch quality.

A lot of people are afraid to go Mac because they are so used to WIndows but take it from a long time Windows user, after a few montsh playing with these Macs, you will wonder what took you so long to come here!

Best of all you very rarely ever have to worry about any issues with these machines.  My wife has had a G5 for the past 4 years with no problems, while I have been through at least 3 Windows machines and AV programs so it was just inevitable that I would make the move. If you are that afraid of Mac, you can always get a Macbook and install boot camp whcih will allow you to use  Windows but best believe you may ditch it before long!

Let Bill Gates go!

This is an amazing product for the price!  We have our WiFi box and modem upstairs and we put this in the computer room downstairs, on the other side of the house, and it picks up the signal amazingly!  Definitely recommend!!!

Touch screen started acting up within first two months of owning. laptop acted like screen was being touched and clicking things on its own. input_doc: It was the worst gift I've ever given him!  He has a laptop and the Windows 8 really only seems to work well with the touch screen computers.  It's been about 5 months now and we are about ready to toss this piece of junk out and buy a new one.  Last night while he was doing some work remotely, the computer screen went completely blank and he hasn't been able to get it back up since.  I think it's giving me a bigger headache because I have to hear him complain NONSTOP about what a big, expensive piece of garbage this computer is!!!  BE CAUTIOUS BEFORE PURCHASING!!

I purchased this laptop for my parents who only need a computer for email and browsing the internet. At first, I was very impressed with the fast startup time, very light unit, doesn't get hot, etc.....After a bit of use though, i had problems connecting to their wifi. I would get it connected and then the next day they would say it lost the connection, even though other devices would stay connected (it was not a network issue). In the end, I ended up returning this machine for this reason AND mostly because it is soooo small and compact that it's not suited for folks of my parents' age. The screen and icons are very tiny, they could not function well with such a small display. I might have pushed them to suffer through this had it not been for the connectivity problem (I googled it, it's a recurring issue with this machine). input_doc:
I originally bought this for my theater room which has a projector, and 7.1 system.  I also have an ABUS system with keypads that allows music to be played in various rooms in my home.  I liked the idea of a networked receiver which could find and play my music stored on various computers hooked into the network.  As time has gone on, however, I have found this receiver (and those like it) to become more and more obsolete.  The Audyssey is a nice feature for setting up the theater room, but the receiver itself has proven completely useless for managing large music collections. Not only is it way too slow, but limited in it's ability to playback a number of lossless formats.  There are several remote apps available for droid and apple, but they are also cumbersome, and none can actually power on the unit.  I really like it for my theater room as it actually can be a modified 9.1.  I think the sound is terrific.  I have Polk LSI 9s and the LSI C for my Front 3 speakers and my surround speakers are 4 ohm in-ceiling as well, which sound great but tough to drive.  After my Aragon 8008BB, there is no going back to any one-unit-does-all a/v amp, although the Denon adequately drives the surround and center speaker.  All of the rest of my video (home movies, etc.) runs from the computer.

What I am doing now for my ABUS is using a computer as a server which I can access via smart phone or ipad using Plex which can stream both audio or video as well as online radio, including Spotify and Pandora. I don't use anything with RGB or RCA video anymore, and hooking up an ipod dock is way over as a technology.  In my mind, All-in-one receivers like this are on the way out as networked computers can provide most of it's functions.  It will be going up for sale.

As a young man, I started out trying to get the best amplifier with speakers I could afford.  It then expanded into DSP preamps, tuners, phonograph, tape players, CD and DVD players.  It is ironic to me that after the many years and 1000s of dollars I have spent on various equipment, that I am back where I started, which is putting my $ into the best amplifier and speakers I can afford with a computer to do the rest.

Sorry but I spent months debating about what headphone to buy. I was leery about spending this kind of money on headphones. I have to tell you after trying all the best and top brands: Sony, Beats by Dre, JVC, Seinheisser, etc. These destroy them. You can't tell from the photo but the frame is metal and it is covered by this slick black coating. Underneath the metal your head is supported by this "memory foam feeling gell type" layer which is soooooo comfortable. I love the braded cord that comes with it; slightly short but hell spend a few bucks to get an extension cable. The cord also has volume controls with a play button which works on my iPod 5th Gen.

input_doc: This adapter gave me trouble from the first time I connected it to my laptop...first I download the driver from the box and then I went online and downloaded the 8.1 driver for....the computer is only 25 to 35 yards away from the wireless router and the highest signal strength it gets was 86 Mbps wish I thought was crazy. And then every 10 to 15 minutes the Internet connection always goes off disconnect and then I have to either reconnect by unplugging it and plugged it back in over and over again...then it totally stop working completely...and I call the seller and he said he would replace it with another one...in which I hope to get soon.

UPDATED:

This unit fully supports 3 HDMI 1080P through with full 5.1 & 7.1 LPCM support. If your Blu-Ray (PS3) is set to output LPCM then DTS HD adn DOLBY HD output as LPCM and sound great Supports full 24 bit / 192 khz 7.1 and sounds really, really good.

I wish the digital was more easily re-assignable. For example, my Comcast box HDMI has to be accessed through the "SAT" button, and my computer audio is on the "TV" button. Programmable button commands (my old Panasonic had) would have made this perfect for the money.

A great buy!!!

I just ordered this from Sony (product available on 4/4/08, so I have three weeks or so until they ship.) I had a DG710 and although the description read that it accepted LPCM through HDMI the reality was it only accepted 2.1 LPCM through HDMI! You have to use Bitstream and DD or DTS for 5.1 or 6.1.

I was furious, I contacted Sony customer support and they didn't know the DG710 didn't play 5.1 LPCM! They told me it was defective. I returned it and the same problem occurred with the new one. So I am returning the new one and I ordered the new DG720. All the Sony STRDG models have been upgraded to from 510, 710, 810 and 910 to 520. 720, 820 and 920. The difference, now they all handle surround LCPM. The STRDG720 also has 1 more HDMI than the 710, and that's exactly what I need so I am very happy about that change.

If it doesn't work I will update this review around the middle of April.

I have tried Soooooooo many of these; Some, the tip would not pick up and when u press harder , it wouldn't slide; the tip would have too much rubber and it would come off and it would just bend weird, not giving me a comfortable feeling. I ordered this one because the picture showed a different tip on the stylus than the one I am used to. The tip is actually the same as other styluses, BUT, this one is WAY more responsive, and for the size, it' very accurate and it requires very little pressure. It also slides on the screen quite nicely.

Update: adapter quick working suddenly and would not power on at all.  However the seller has it setup super easy to get a refund .

My laptop would only pick up 2.4 Ghz signal  but I needed an option to get a 5Ghz signal since that signal was so much faster on speedtest. The setup was pretty much painless. On my laptop when I selected the wifi networks I noticed that the device creates a 'WiFi 2' category that has all the same networks that the 'WiFi' category had. I turned off the original laptop's wifi and made sure the wifi 2 category was selected. This will enable you to access the wifi signals through this device. Like magic it allowed me to connect to the my Router's 5Ghz signal and now my internet is much faster. Great product!!!

input_doc: I enjoy this tablet, but I think it has some major flaws. I'll start with what I like. It has a good size, and I really like the free office for a year. It runs little games pretty well, and the keyboard is nice. It takes some getting used to since it's small, but it works good. However, my trackpad was placed on the tablet skewed so it doesn't work. The cover thing for the trackpad doesn't lay flat and therefore has never worked. I went out and bought a wireless mouse for it so I'm not too upset about it. It sure was annoying it figure that out though, so be warned that your trackpad might be defective. Also, my right speaker on the bad doesn't work. So..... that's fun. And I already have notes on here for one of my classes I'm taking right now so I can't return it until that class is done. I'm disappointed that so many defects are apparent in my purchase. I think I would be a different one if I could go back in time, but it does what I bought it to do. Which is take notes in class. I just wanted to stream music from it while I study :(

input_doc: I bought this camera to watch my screen porch during the day after a couple of incidents of trespassing. It works OK in the day. The integrated web server and motion sensing is a necessary feature since if you don't want to have to have a computer running all day to monitor the video for motion. The wireless network card isn't great- I get like 40% connectivity to my router that's about 30 feet and 2 rooms away. However, most wireless cameras don't offer WPA2 encryption and I'd never go back to the incredibly insecure WEP just to run a wireless camera. That said, I bought a D-Link DWL-P50 Power over Ethernet (PoE) Adapter so that I can run power-over-Ethernet to the camera because I think the wireless is a little sketchy and it's easy to saturate the limited bandwidth that the card can handle. I haven't yet had the courage to cut and splice the camera power adapter to use it with PoE. Obviously, the PoE power cord doesn't fit in the camera receptacle, which is a shame. The email feature works about 70% of the time, the ftp feature works more often. I don't see how to enable the NTP feature so I have to manually set the time every time the camera is unplugged. Two of the best features are the ability to turn off the blue LED and the stand. The stand is highly configurable. However, the lens is useless at night. I installed a 200W halogen motion light about the porch door and the camera captures a images when the light comes on, but they're so poor as to be useless. All in all, a decent camera on the cheap. It's no Axis, but it's reasonably priced.

input_doc: The Magnasonic iPhone/iPod clock radio is a basic little box that does what it says it will do. It will play FM stations and allows for 20 pre-programmed ones. It will play and sync your iPod and allows you to navigate among your songs by next and previous buttons. It offers two alarms and a snooze. The sound is okay--neither very good nor very bad. The machine is not beautiful, but it's also not ugly. The button functionality is not immediately intuitive, but you can eventually make sense of it. (I noticed at least a couple errors in the directions, which makes things that much harder.) There's no way I would rely on it as my main alarm clock because of how difficult it would be to operate the machine when not mentally acute. (The BEST, most intuitive alarm clock I have ever owned--and I've owned a number--is this one: Sony ICFC180 AM/FM Clock Radio.) But it would be okay to have this one by your desk or in your kitchen to use as a source of music and, very occasionally, as an alarm. I plugged my iPod Touch 2g into the machine at first and was met by the disheartening message that the device was not supported by the iPod, but that turned out not to be true: a nudge or two and it worked okay. With my Incipio case on, however, the connection between the iPod Touch and the clock radio was not very secure. It didn't take much for the connection to break, though if I fiddled with it I could get it to work. Without the case the connection was better. Best yet, however, was when I plugged in my daughter's iPod Nano 3g, which fit very snugly. She consequently inherits the clock radio. In short, it's a serviceable device that may suit your needs, depending on what your needs are. -- Debra Hamel

input_doc:
Absolute garbage. I had 7 ports in use out of 10, and came back home, found out ports were dead.
Checked with other computers I had, and didn't work.
I opened it up, nonetheless, IC for USB controller was burnt.
Funny how they advertise as "total current output: 19V/3.15A; watts:59.85W".
I don't think so. I bet I was using waaaay less power than max. power output. Some ports were connected but weren't even in use (ie. USB phone charge cable)

One of the shift keys is programed as a Tab Key which makes typing impossible and the way the front lip of this is set, you have to lift your hands above the product to use it. input_doc: I bought this notebook a month ago. It's tiny and lightweight, which is great when traveling. When I am not traveling, which is most of the time, it's a little too small. The monitor is 12.1", but with LCD prices dropping, I guess I'll buy one soon. The keyboard is too small for comfort, but I bought the Logitech Wireless Desktop from Amazon for 29.99. The USB ports and all other ports are one the side, which is a little messier than having them all in the back. The fan was a little noisy, but I calibrated it, and now it's fine. It runs extremely well, and I guess all in all, I am very happpy with my purchase. The price is great with this much memory, HD space, and a DVD-RW. I give it 4 stars.

input_doc:
MBP users should know that while this product is a perfect size for the 15" model and it definitely keeps your laptop cooler, there is an issue.  The design of the USB connection has the cord attached at the back.  In order to make sure that it doesn't block your power connection, you must bend the USB cord waaay down.  There is still danger of your power connection not being completely in contact as it should be.  Also, with the short length of the coolpad's USB power connector, there isn't an option to plug it in on the other side of your MBP.

O, and if you plan to use this on your lap, look first at the contours of the bottom.  Although the large feet make a great base on a hard surface, you may want to use a lapboard or something similar between the plastic edges of the bottom surface and your legs.

input_doc:
I purposely choose not to spend $50+ on earbuds due to losing them or destroying them on a somewhat regular basis (same rule I apply to sunglasses).  I purchased to replace a lost set of older JVC (HAFX66A) earbuds that I absolutely loved.  My needs have changed a bit and I needed a pair that would put up with running as well as had a built-in MIC for phone calls.  My last two sets of earbuds (HA-FX66 & HA-FX34) have been JVC and I have been very pleased with them, so I figured I would give these a shot.

PROS
 - very clear sound quality
 - comfortable fit (may take some adjustment time)
 - stay in place
 - waterproof
 - MIC and Button work properly on iPhone6
 - MIC works properly on Windows laptop

CONS
 - limited bass
 - short cord is too short....with extension..too long

I cannot directly compare these HA-ETR40 to my older JVC since well...they are all lost.  However I can compare them to my much older ME-M6P earbuds which somehow I have not lost after 6 years.  I know for sure I preferred the sound quality of the older HA-FX66 over the ME-M6P.  But comparing the newer HA-ETR40 to the ME-M6P, I prefer the ME-M6P mostly due to the lack of bass from the HA-ETR40.  If the MIC was still functional on my ME-M6P, I would just use those.  Pretty sure years of these things (ME-M6P) being wadded up in my laptop bag has taken its toll.

Limited Bass -- This is very subjective to each user for sure.  My music tastes jump all over the place from Country, Rock, Alternative, Rap, Techno, and Classical depending on my mood and task at hand.  While sitting in my office which is quiet, placing the HA-ETR40 properly in my ears, fully sealed, the bass is there....until I swap in the ME-M6P and realize it really wasn't.  My "assumption" here is that my personal preference is for sure bass heavy and the ME-M6P is not balanced properly...but it is what I like.  What really kills it for me is that since the bass is somewhat weak, when I run I tend to leave the volume low and the earbuds are not fully seated so I can still hear noises around me.  This just makes the lack of bass that much more painful.

input_doc: I purchased this laptop for my parents who only need a computer for email and browsing the internet. At first, I was very impressed with the fast startup time, very light unit, doesn't get hot, etc.....After a bit of use though, i had problems connecting to their wifi. I would get it connected and then the next day they would say it lost the connection, even though other devices would stay connected (it was not a network issue). In the end, I ended up returning this machine for this reason AND mostly because it is soooo small and compact that it's not suited for folks of my parents' age. The screen and icons are very tiny, they could not function well with such a small display. I might have pushed them to suffer through this had it not been for the connectivity problem (I googled it, it's a recurring issue with this machine). My initial thought was it would be worth the money since the price was decent. So I ordered it and was expecting to be blown away after reading the reviews but not so much.

The lens cap is a great fit and used all the time.

input_doc:
I bought this camera because it had underwater capbilites,and we were taking our computer on vacation and I thought it would be fun to review some pictures as the trip progressed.  Considering the price..this camera did great! We snorkled everyday...and got some great shots...you can't expect wonders, but I was plesantly surprised. We photographed a sleeping sea turle, sting rays, and lots of little reef fish...all were clearly visible, some well lit and very colorful, others blurry.  The kids loved seeing themselves snorkling. I have an old underwater Canon (sureshot- 35mm) which takes better pictures....but this camera just gave us another option. Our outdoor pictures came out pretty good, too...although, as the other reviewer said...conditions have to be just right to get good pictures.
This camera is not without it's faults.  Like any cheap piece of electronics it occasionally does crazy stuff.  The last day diving we lost our pictures, because one of the kids may have pressed the wrong buttons in some sequence...or...the batteries ran out...or the camera program just froze.  Battery life does seem a little short..and if they die...you lose your pictures..which is a bummer. The pictures can also be somewhat "pixely,"  especially if you zoom in and crop closely.
My 10 year old loves this camera..and we have had lots of fun with it.  It's small, lightweight, and waterproof in the case. We bought one for her best friend, and they love to go around taking photos, then running in and putting them on the computer to "see what they have."  Photos can be a range of quality...but again.....it's a $24.00 camera.

input_doc:
I'm a systems engineer at a relatively large company, so I'm writing this review from that perspective only. VMware, Hyper-V, ConfigMgr 2012, concerns like that. I'll be RDP'd into 10-20 systems at a time, not always through mRemote. Running this device on Windows 8, the T650 works pretty well. I'm not impressed with gesture functionality. "Wait, do I drag with four fingers or three?" Takes a bit of time to get used to them and frankly, I find the hotcorners more than enough for my purposes. Besides...I don't know many people that do what I do even bothering to use the new Start screen (aka "Metro" interface). We still live in the desktop.

Bringing up the charms by dragging from the edge....works maybe one out of four times. Almost like its set to ignore that gesture lest it get inadvertently repeated.

Where gestures really fall over, as I hinted at before, is when you are RDP'd into something. Of course, that is NO fault of the Logitech software. But it is something to keep in mind. I've got three screens, two of them with RDP sessions open, another for Outlook / Skype / Lync. It takes more work to use gestures in those circumstances.

I'm able to navigate between all three screens relatively quickly. About as accurate as my mouse and not much need for backtracking or overshooting the target. Its great for using Lightroom.

Everyone complaining about click and drag needs to spend more time with this unit before giving up. Use your thumb to hold, your finger to drag. Works fine.

Placement of the T650 is an issue. I cannot get comfortable with it. Maybe I'm simply too used to my mouse. I keep dropping two fingers on the surface of the T650, inadvertently double clicking on something or activating a gesture. Holding three fingers in the air, with another running across the surface of the trackpad, because of its size, gets difficult if running through large spreadsheets or moving objects from my right screen to the left screen.

I suspect after a few more weeks, I'll go back to my mouse and give up on this experiment. It would be nice if I didn't live on my desktop 10 hours a day.

I bought 3 of these and one had to be returned because it was dead on arrival. Very hard to set up and I'm somewhat computer literate.  Instructions are not very good....they lose something in the Chinese to English language.  The two working cameras are ok, would not recommend to anyone who's expectations are too high, but for the money and willing to lose it, I guess it's ok.  It worries me that the DDNS is for 2 years, then what?  But then it may not last that long.  It seems to have a mind of it's own and will rotate like a crazy robot at times.....that can't be normal operation.  The camera came with a $15 rebate, if I said something nice about it or a newer camera if not happy.  Will have to see where this takes me.  Maybe their more expensive and newer cameras are better; this model only gets a 3 star because it is functioning at the moment, but I'm sure there are better cameras out there that are better. input_doc:
I personally wanted to give this a 2 star... but then I had to consider the price and gave it a 3 star.

The volume f11 and f12 do not work.
The nearly four inch wrist rest is to deep, its very uncomfortable to type when sitting at the table with this laptop ( the edges are actually sharp).

It has a overall "cheap" feeling ...I guess because it is inexpensive  ( I keep trying to remember that fact).
I do like the size of the touch pad, but the buttons don't feel like they will last.
I am not a fan of the low profile keyboard either ( however all newer computers seem to have them now).

It did boot up fine ... and the computer itself seems to be working well ( this is my 3 Dell, so I'm a repeat customer)  but the case/ or shell appears substandard.

So if this is back up ...or if you are using it with a TV, I'm sure its a great buy ....if its for everyday use, this may not be the one. ( I'll update this review in a month or so ...after I have used it for a while).

 I am trying to tell myself I will get used to windows 8 ....so far I don't believe myself.

***************
 I want to update my review ,  I have decided to return this laptop.  With the 2 function keys not working and and the right button on on the mouse pad sticking ....  I decided that it had to much against it , for a BRAND new computer. ( even a inexpensive one).

I was unsure about my ability to return the defective laptop , because it was not actually "dead on arrival"  and I had used it for several days ...  I sent a detailed message to Amazon , and in less than 24 HR I was sent a return label.

I have always been 100% pleased with AMAZON and with this situation they rose to the occasion.  I am slightly concerned , because the "reason" for the return on the label says "different from what was ordered"  and that is not the case ... other than I ordered a laptop that should not be defective.  I am hopeful that the return process goes well ... and I look forward to buying a new laptop as soon as my credit it processed .
GPT-4o_MA:

input_doc:
This is close to being a perfect example of a wearable/mountable POV camera. But unfortunately, close isn't quite good enough.

The pros:
Video is awesome, in all of the modes.
Stills are very good quality, the timelapse feature is fantastic.
It's waterproof.
The mounting options are (almost) limitless.

The cons:
It's awkward to set up. Menu is like something from 20 years ago.
Firmware issues have yet to be addressed by the manufacturer. This is inexcusable as the camera has been available for sale for nearly a year.
Audio is useless. They could have saved weight and cost by just not including a mic. The only instance where it even sort of works is when mounted right near a loudish sound you want to highlight, such as an engine.
There are too many instances where "Macgyvering" is required to get the desired result. The quick release mount rattles so you need to tape the base plate, the non waterproof back allows too much wind noise, so you need to tape over the openings, the shutter button rattles, so you need to tape over that. Moral of the story: BUY TAPE.
The support by the manufacturer is not quite adequate. I realize it's a small start up company, but for all the issues with the use of the camera and the handling/editing of the files, they really need to release some conclusive videos or articles to address these concerns.

People who might find this camera useful:
Auto racing enthusiasts
Mountain Bikers
Sailors
Hobbyist videographers looking for those unique shots

People who will likely be disappointed and frustrated by this camera:
Pretty much anyone who thinks they'll be using it as a camcorder.
People who aren't really tech savvy and/or have an older computer
People who don't like to tinker and engineer solutions to make it do what they want.

******UPDATE******* ******UPDATE******* ******UPDATE******* ******UPDATE******* ******UPDATE*******
As of September 7, 2010, Gopro released the new firm ware for the camera. It seems to have fixed most of the bugs/issues. It also provides the option for upside down mounting.
My Best SONY VAIO Computer of 6...  Very fast i7 with great storage and display clarity...  Sooo sad SONY is not making this VAIO model any more...

So far so good. Didnt notice a giant speed increase and seems to have steadied out as far as increasing boot times. It fires uop your most used programs quickly towards the beginning but i think as you start using it the 8g of ssd becomes more clogged slowing it down a bit so then your back to having a 7200rpm HD. However for the price it did make me give it 4 stars because it has plenty of storage for what iu neeed and did somewhat increase speeds. If you really want to see the different every time you start up PC and open programs get a real SSD. If you need storage and a fast drive, get this. I edit photos and video and have not had any lag with this. Renders, load, opens etc much faster than some of the WD greens i use for quiet long term storage. I also have a couple other 7200pm drives and this is a little faster for sure.

Decided to upgrade my 1TB WD Blue drive to this blazing SSD on my Lenovo Thinkpad E440 which I bought in sept 2014. I was thinking of getting a Kingfast drive over at alibaba but after reading so much positive reviews about the 850 pro drives,i decided to go on with my maiden 512GB ssd purchase. I did not use the migration tool as i installed win 7 pro from scratch.shipping to singapore was fast, about 5 working days.overall i am loving this ssd.boots up in less than 12secs and shut down in less than 15 secs. input_doc:
Pros-
-Great screen, not too much glare for a glossy screen, amazing colors, and decent definition (1080)
-Beautiful design/style, entire thing only uses 3 metal plates, I still smile when I look at it
-All the internal parts are perfectly positioned so that your hands won't feel heat under loads
-Build quality is exceptional, everything fits together so nicely
-Swapping parts is quick and easy (and possible)
-More powerful than most desktops, the i7 and GTX 850m will handle pretty much anything out there.
-Has an ASUS logo on the back that lights up when the laptop's on
-All major ports are on the left side, so there won't be any wires bothering your mouse (assuming your right handed)
-DVD/optional blu ray player (which can be replaced with an additional hard drive bay if needed)
-It's about $XXX cheaper than most other laptops with the same specs, It really is a great deal
-Boots surprisingly fast considering the 5400rpm HDD
-Quiet machine even with fans running at max speed
-Discrete fans, air flows in through 2 small vents under it, and out through the back where the monitor axis are
-Everything about this laptop has a very high quality feel, even the charging brick.
-Decent sound quality, the mini sub woofer helps
-I have never seen goat simulator run smoother than on this machine, most games on max will go 60fps+
-Battery life is alright I guess it should last through a few lectures or classes

Cons-
-Backlit keyboard sprays light all around the keys, and depending on the angle is brighter than the letters
-The shift key came slightly tilted to the left (minor detail)
-The left arrow is about 0.1mm lower than the other keys (minor detail)
-The stickers on it (Intel i7, Energy star, and GTX 850m) were tilted at a slightly off angle (minor detail)
-I had to buy a t5 screw head to open the back to add more ram (it only comes with 8gb, but there's and empty slot) (minor detail)
-Indicator lights (like for power/wireless/blutooth/etc) are small and not very visible. (minor detail)
-Battery is good considering the power, but still is only 2-5 hours depending on what you're running
-HDD running at 5400rpm kinda sucks, but it's replaceable so whatever, at least its a quiet one
-Only one built in hardrive bay, if needed you can replace the DVD thingy with a bay (minor detail)
-Its not free

I did my research on laptops (for a bit too long) and found that this was the best, the pros defiantly overwrite the cons. I really was unsure, I stared at the "place order" page for about 3 days, but it really was a good deal, and it was sooo worth it. It does have flaws, but they are all very minor and don't really make a difference. This really is the best laptop that you'll get for under 2 grand.

input_doc:
My car is a 2004 and the radio can't handle MP3 CDs.  This gadget works great.  Sure, the sound suffers a bit under the limited bandwidth of FM radio, and your options to navigate and chose songs are pretty limited.  I wish you could actually see the track and album info on the device, which would make searching for music soooo much easier.  I play from the SD card and have about 1.5GB of music on it that I totally like, so I let it shuffle (random choice of songs on the SD card) and that works absolutely perfect for me.
As its power is obviously from the 12V board power of the car, be aware how the outlet of your car is wired.  Mine provides power even with ignition off and keys removed - so pull it out when your leaving the car unattended for many days, and I pause it to not play continuously when I leave the car. I am ambidextrous & I have always used my mouse lefthanded.  I find the Logitech Trackball the best!!!  I have switched my clicks so to speak & now what would have been done on the ball w/right I do left!  This is a time saving, arm saving & finger saving device!  The only problem I have ever had after 3 years is making sure my batteries don't run out in mid-type!  They last over a year so it isn't even a hardship.

input_doc:
This is a good overall card if you don't need to the speed, but you can find many other models that will match the speed of this card.

Basically Lexar is claiming a maximum write speed of 90MB/s, this is completely false through all of my testing. The claim of a 45MB/s write speed is also false.

As a control, I was using a SanDisk 16GB 30MB/s card.

Using Crystal Disk Mark:

Lexar 600x  |  Sandisk 233x

Read [MB/s}, Write [MB/s]  |  Read [MB/s}, Write [MB/s]

31.18,  22.83  |  31.07,  28.01

As you can see, the 2 year old regular Sandisk scored better than the Pro Lexar card in write speed. Keep in mind I was using the Lexar Pro USB 3.0 reader.

This is a valuable metric, but it isn't always telling. It was time to test the card head to head in my camera.

Canon EOS 60D: 10 Raw Shots, Time to clear buffer. "The ultimate test"

The Sandisk scored an average of 10.85 seconds to clear the buffer in my 60D. The Lexar took 10.92 seconds, a tie.

The next test is where I thought the lexar would come into it's own. The primary marketing fact on this page ^^^ is that the Lexar is superior in transfer speed to the computer, nope.

Transfering the same 20 Raw shots to the computer using USB 3.0 Pro Lexar reader.

Sandisk: 13.55 seconds
Lexar: 13.56

Another tie.

--------

Conclusion, and other metrics.

I am shocked that my $14 Sandisk tied with this $70 card, it even beat it in some instances. So, I would absolutely recommend the $14 Sandisk Extreme "HD Video" card over this one. If you want the speed. Get the Sandisk Extreme Pro cards. They are simply the fastest.

Regardless of speed, the Lexar seems likes a solid card, build quality is high and get noticeably less hot than other cards. I did a few "corruption tests" such as ripping the card out of the reader when it was still reading from the card. Even under these circumstances, the card never delivered a corrupt image. (A problem I have had in the past with SanDisk). It is for these reasons that the cards receives a rating of "3 stars". Otherwise, steer clear. You can get a way better deal on a SanDisk (or probably other brand).

input_doc:
I've only had this a few days, but my initial impressions are very positive.

Basically it does everything you would expect it to do.  Power it on, connect to your computer, load it with content, download the app, set your device's wi-fi connection to connect to the wi-drive, start the app...and that's it.

Within the first hour - the USB connection for pushing content to it is sloooooow - I had an iphone, ipod touch and my Kindle Fire streaming 3 different movies perfectly well.

What I especially liked on the Kindle is you get a list of the movies!!  No more guessing with that stupid, idiotic Gallery view in the Kindle App that only shows you thumbnails and forces you to guess the movie!

It's not a full, true, wi-fi connection - so I couldn't get it to stream well from 50 feet away - but since you'll likely be sitting right next to it, you should be fine.

Battery life is actually going to be the limitation at around 4 hours (I believe), but checkout other reviews as people have discovered a workaround to get it to charge whilst streaming (which it doesn't want to do natively).

This is an out-of-the-box solution for the BBO in need of portability and efficiency. I compared this product to the WIZO Foldable Bluetooth Keyboard (see the WIZO Foldable Bluetooth Keyboard product, review entitled Uhggg!, October 10, 2016).

iClever =
- Easy to set-up
- Durable
- Very little learning curve to adjust fingers to mini-keyboard

The attached images are comparing the WIZO Foldable Bluetooth Keyboard to the standard keyboard I use for business and this iClever product.

I'll be back later to post an update to see if a four or five-star rating is warranted.  So far, I'm headed in that direction.

I wanted to purchase a gaming laptop and this laptop fit exactly what I wanted.

The feel and looks of it are fantastic. I love backlit keyboards so that was a plus.

It runs my games perfectly well (League of Legends on High at around 120fps, Overwatch on Medium at around 70fps, and processes games like Civ 5 and Sins of a Solar Empire quickly) and without effort.

Startup is incredibly quick (Gotta love Solid State!) but you may notice that the signing in process (Windows 10) kinda takes a bit but I don't believe that to be due to the laptop. Also, sometimes that process is faster than other times.

input_doc: For the price, this is awesome.... love the screen size!

Someone recommended these to me as a cheaper alternative to some expensive high quality brand a guy at a store was trying to sell me. typically when it comes to headphones i just buy skullcandy or gummy cause they are chep, but they also usually quit on me juuust after warranty/or a few months. i plan on starting a podcast and need something better for recording. these are the best sounding headphones I have ever owned. the only thing i don't like about them is they cover half my head but thats something i'll just have to get used to. they have a long ass (10ft?) cord and comfy ear cushions. once i have had them longer i may update, but sooo worth the price

input_doc: Works great and breathed new life into my laptop letting me play some games that I couldn't play before with just onboard video.  As most know you can't upgrade your video card in a laptop.  My laptop has a true docking station, not just a port replicator that people call a docking station.  The Docking station has a PCI card slot in it like a normal PC would.  When I am "docked", Windows 7 thinks I have two video cards.  When I play StarCraft II, I a able to disable the internal card, shut the lid and use my external monitor and dock video card.  It is sooo sweet! input_doc: This TV is great, it's my 3rd samsung i've purchased and definitely the best, I bought one of the earlier LED TV samsungs and they are great but the interface on this newer model is amazing. It's sooo easy to use, the build quality is like German engineering, even the remote exudes German quality even though it's from Korea. I think Samsung have taken quality build to the next level with this product. It isn't kitchy, it's quality, love it highly recommended. I thought of buying the more expensive ones but this one is perfect, i've not a 50/60/75hz or whatever it is snob, the picture quality is AMAZING and unlike the older Samsung LED TV's the sound quality is superb. input_doc: For a laptop at this price, I would expect it to work.  I had it for six months and from the first week I had problems.  It suddenly became slow, crashed all the time, the camera, the touchscreen, and the keyboard would randomly decide not to work for days.  And while I was using it the other day the screen randomly went black and I haven't beeen able to use it since and I can't get my documents or pictures that I need off of it. Sony's customer service is the worst ever.  They will only do repairs and they refuse tt do replacements even though repairs take weeks and I am a student and do not have time to go without a laptop for that long. input_doc: I bought these as a potential upgrade to the Koss Porta Pros that I have been using for many years. In my opinion sound quality and clarity were very good, but only almost as good as the less expensive Porta Pros. My main complaint about the ATH-FC700As is that they were very uncomfortable for me to wear for any extended period of time. In order for the ATH-FC700As to provide some sound isolation (there is some sound leakage) they clamp down pretty tightly. After about an hour or so they started hurting my ears, whereas with the Porta Pros I'm able to adjust the tension of the ear pieces and they are comfortable all day (I use them all day while working at my computer). My suggestion is if you like the style and are only going to wear your headphones for an hour or two at a time then these are a good choice, but if you are like me and use your headphones for extended periods of time there are better options out there that cost much less such as the Porta Pros.Koss PortaPro Headphones with Case

input_doc: While this monitor is great it does have it's flaws, My issue is I should of done a little more research before I purchased it.  So the mains issue i have is that this monitor is for consoles, I don't play games on consoles I prefer to game on pc's.  But doing research and watching video review I could of found out this ahead of time.  The ghosting on my unit had very bad ghosting which is very noticeable even during gaming and even worse on text on webpages.  While disabling ama does help this but doing so causing another problem like fuzz during movement, so I decided to return this display.  Yes the image is nice the colors are decent but for pc I would not recommend this product.  I work on my computer and play games as much as I can and cant see myself continuing using this display with these issues, but those with consoles its definitely a decent choice.  So I hope I can help someone out there that don't make the same mistake that i did, while the price is very compelling you got to ask yourself especially if your going to use it for pc, can you deal with the possibility of having the same issues and can you live with it?  There are some greater options out there definitely do the research before the purchase thank you!!!!
